Tiger Hill in Darjeeling is undoubtedly famous for its breathtaking sunrise view and the stunning sight of the Kanchenjunga mountain range. However, my recent visit left me with mixed feelings, highlighting the need for better attention and management.First, the positives. The view from Tiger Hill is nothing short of awe-inspiring. Watching the sunrise paint the sky with hues of orange and pink while the mighty Kanchenjunga stands tall is an experience that's hard to put into words. It's a sight that should be on every traveler's bucket list.That said, the visit could be more enjoyable with some improvements. The crowd here can be overwhelming, and I couldn't help but worry about safety. Authorities should consider better crowd management measures before an unmonitored crowd leads to accidents.Additionally, the entry ticket system seems reasonable, but it could be more organized to reduce waiting times.One major downside during my visit was the ongoing construction of an observatory building, which added to the frustration. It obstructed the view and disrupted the otherwise tranquil atmosphere. I hope that once completed, it enhances the overall experience rather than detracting from it.Lastly, a piece of advice for future visitors: the view is undoubtedly great, but it can be hindered by bad weather. It's essential to check the weather forecast before planning an early morning visit, as often suggested by tourist guides. Mother Nature can be unpredictable, and fog or rain can obscure the panoramic views.In conclusion, Tiger Hill's natural beauty is undeniable, and the sunrise view is a must-see. However, there's room for improvement in crowd management, ticketing, and minimizing construction-related disruptions. Visitors should be mindful of weather conditions for the best experience. With some attention and proper management, Tiger Hill can continue to be a memorable destination for all.Tiger Hill in Darjeeling is undoubtedly famous for its breathtaking sunrise view and the stunning sight of the Kanchenjunga mountain range. The square church tower of Christ Church, painted a pale creamy yellow, is one of the Shimla skyline’s most prominent highlights. The church is one of North India’s oldest churches, its cornerstone having been laid in 1844, and the church consecrated in January 1857. Today, Christ Church is part of the Church of North India’s Diocese of Amritsar, and regular services in English and Hindi are held every Sunday.Visitors, however, are allowed into the church, though (of course) you are expected to maintain decorum. Photography is allowed (no videography), but only till before the pews—there are signs to this effect. Also, visitors can enter only up to the last two pews, so it’s not possible to walk along the sides (which have some beautiful stained-glass windows) or up to the altar (also good stained-glass at the back). The walls are lined with many plaques of polished brass, commemorating various people, both British and Indian, who lived and/or died in Shimla and around.The square church tower of Christ Church, painted a pale creamy yellow, is one of the Shimla skyline’s most prominent highlights. Christ Church is one the oldest churches in North India and was built by the British in 1857 to serve the large Anglican British community in the area. The majestic appearance of the church and its stunning location makes it a prime attraction in Shimla. The church has stained glass windows, which represents faith, hope, charity, fortitude, patience, and humanity. It is one of the long lasting legacies of British rule in India and also Shimla's most popular landmark. Built by British, used to be summer home for Indian President and now a center for advanced studies for few lucky. One of the must visit places in Shimla which has a rich history, is very beautiful and well maintained. There is a 15 min guided tour inside the Lodge every 30 min and each slot has limited quota. No photography is allowed inside the Lodge. Last slot is at 4.30PM as this place closes at 5PM. Guided tour along with access to outer area and botanical garden is charged 100/- for adults and 50/- for kids. If not interested in tour, visitors can pay 30/- for entrance. Recommend to have the guided tour at least once to witness the beauty of this marvellous wooden architecture from inside and know it's history. Vehicles can drop visitors at the fire station near this Lodge and go back to parking area below. Entrance tickets are bought at this fire station which is also used as a book stall and snacks area. Washrooms are behind this fire station.Visited on
Weekend

Jakhoo Temple, located in Shimla, Himachal Pradesh, is one of the captivating and spiritually significant destination. Jakhoo Temple is renowned for its serene ambiance and the awe-inspiring statue of Lord Hanuman. You can take Ropeway or a taxi to reach there and Beware of Monkeys, they try to snatch your belongings. The temple is perched atop Jakhoo Hill, the highest point in Shimla, which offers breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding landscape. The main attraction of the temple is the massive 108-feet tall statue of Lord Hanuman. The Ridge is a popular open space located in the heart of Shimla, a beautiful hill station in the northern Indian state of Himachal Pradesh. It is a wide open road that runs along the Mall Road and connects it to the famous Scandal Point.The Ridge Shimla offers panoramic views of the surrounding mountains and valleys and is a popular tourist destination for its picturesque setting. It is a popular spot for leisurely walks, picnics, and outdoor activities like horse riding and skating.The Ridge also hosts several cultural events and festivals throughout the year, including the Summer Festival, which is a major attraction for tourists. It is also home to some of the city's most iconic landmarks, such as the Christ Church, the Ridge Monument, and the Gaiety Theater.Overall, The Ridge Shimla is a must-visit destination for anyone visiting Shimla, offering a delightful blend of natural beauty, cultural significance, and recreational activities.The Ridge is a popular open space located in the heart of Shimla, a beautiful hill station in the northern Indian state of Himachal Pradesh. It is a wide open road that runs along the Mall Road and connects it to the famous Scandal Point.

The Kali Bari Temple was originally built in 1845 by a Bengali Brahmin 'Ram Charan Brahmachari' in the vicinity of the Rathani Fort on the Jakhu Hills.  It is one of the oldest temples in the city and features a unique Hindu-style architecture.  Later, the British shifted the location of the temple to this new location.  The temple is located amidst the green hills of Shimla and offers a serene and peaceful environment, perfect for anyone who wants to get away from the hustle and bustle of city life.  The overall atmosphere is truly spiritual and rejuvenating.  It is a must visit place in Shimla.Every day visitors worship Goddess Kali here.  As the temple is slightly uphill, one has to go up to get there.  So elderly people may suffer a little.  Upon entering the compound you will automatically find peace and truly enjoy the tranquility in the middle of the city.  The view of the city from the temple premises is very beautiful.Visited on
Weekend

काली बाड़ी मन्दिर (Kali Bari Mandir) भारत के हिमाचल प्रदेश के शिमला नगर में स्थित एक हिन्दू मन्दिर है। यह काली माता के श्यामला रूप को समर्पित है और इन्ही श्यामला माता पर शिमला नगर का नाम पड़ा है। माना जाता है कि इन देवी का मूल स्थान जाखू था।[1]

Kali Bari Mandir is a Hindu temple located in Shimla city of Himachal Pradesh, India. It is dedicated to the Shyamala form of Kali Mata and the city of Shimla is named after this Shyamala Mata. It is believed that the original place of these goddesses was Jakhu.[1]

Visiting the rose garden was an enchanting experience that delighted all my senses. As I stepped through the entrance, I was immediately greeted by an overwhelming wave of fragrant blooms that seemed to embrace the air around me. The vibrant colors of the roses painted a picturesque scene that felt like stepping into a fairy tale.Wandering through the pathways, I was astounded by the variety of roses on display. From delicate tea roses to bold and vibrant hybrid varieties, each bloom was a masterpiece in its own right. The meticulous care taken to arrange them by color and size was evident, creating a harmonious symphony of hues that danced before my eyes.The garden's layout was thoughtfully designed, offering different sections that highlighted specific types of roses. A dedicated area for climbers showcased their graceful ascent, while the formal rose beds displayed a tapestry of different colors and shapes. One particularly charming corner featured antique roses, each with a unique story to tell.Amidst the visual feast, the gentle hum of bees and the occasional flutter of butterflies added to the garden's allure. I found myself lost in the tranquility of the surroundings, a temporary escape from the bustling world beyond the garden's borders.The visit was not only a treat for the eyes and nose but also an opportunity to learn. Informational plaques provided insights into the history of various rose breeds, cultivation techniques, and even tips for nurturing roses at home. It was a wonderful blend of beauty and education.As I reluctantly left the garden, I couldn't help but feel a sense of rejuvenation. The experience left me inspired to bring a touch of this enchantment into my own life. The rose garden was more than just a collection of flowers; it was a sanctuary of beauty, a space to connect with nature, and a reminder of the simple joys that the world has to offer.Visiting the rose garden was an enchanting experience that delighted all my senses. The Rose Garden in Ooty is a delightful place that truly lives up to its name. Nestled amidst the picturesque Nilgiri Hills, this garden is a floral paradise that will leave you spellbound.As you step inside, you'll be greeted by a riot of colors and the sweet fragrance of thousands of roses in various hues and varieties. It's a haven for nature lovers and a perfect spot for a leisurely stroll. The well-maintained pathways wind through the garden, making it easy to explore the lush greenery and vibrant blossoms.What's truly remarkable is the sheer diversity of roses on display, from miniature roses to the classic red ones. The garden is meticulously organized, with each section dedicated to different types of roses. It's not just roses; you'll also find various other exotic flowers and plants that add to the garden's charm.The best time to visit is during the blooming season, usually from April to June, when the roses are in full splendor. However, the garden retains its charm year-round, with different flowers taking center stage in different seasons.For those who appreciate the beauty of nature, the Rose Garden in Ooty is a must-visit. It's a serene place to relax, take in the breathtaking views, and revel in the simple yet profound beauty of roses and other flowers. Whether you're a botany enthusiast or just looking for a peaceful escape, this garden promises an enchanting experience. Don't forget to bring your camera to capture the stunning flora in all its glory.The Rose Garden in Ooty is a delightful place that truly lives up to its name. Nestled amidst the picturesque Nilgiri Hills, this garden is a floral paradise that will leave you spellbound.

The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve Office serves as the administrative headquarters for the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, located in the Nilgiri district of Tamil Nadu, India. This review aims to provide insights into the reserve office, its facilities, and its significance for wildlife conservation.1. Location and Accessibility:The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve Office is strategically situated in the vicinity of the Mudumalai Wildlife Sanctuary, making it easily accessible to visitors. It is well-connected by roadways, and the nearest major city, Mysore, is approximately 90 kilometers away. The office's location amidst the lush greenery and natural beauty of the Western Ghats enhances its charm.2. Information Center:The office houses an information center that serves as a valuable resource for visitors. Here, one can find detailed maps, brochures, and other informative materials about the wildlife reserve. The knowledgeable staff members are readily available to provide assistance, answer queries, and offer guidance on planning a visit to the reserve.3. Permit and Entry Procedures:Obtaining permits and entry passes is a crucial part of visiting the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, and the office facilitates this process efficiently. Visitors can acquire the necessary permits, pay the required fees, and obtain relevant information regarding safari options, timings, and regulations. The staff ensures a streamlined entry process, minimizing any inconvenience for visitors.4. Wildlife Conservation Efforts:The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve Office plays a pivotal role in wildlife conservation and protection of the region's rich biodiversity. It serves as a hub for various conservation activities, including monitoring wildlife populations, research initiatives, and implementing conservation programs. The office collaborates with government bodies, local communities, and non-profit organizations to safeguard the natural habitat and promote sustainable practices.5. Interpretation and Education:The office features educational displays and exhibits that shed light on the diverse flora and fauna found within the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve. These exhibits offer visitors a deeper understanding of the region's ecosystems, wildlife species, and conservation challenges. Such interpretive materials contribute to raising awareness about the importance of preserving this precious natural heritage.6. Nature Trails and Eco-Tourism Initiatives:The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve Office provides information on various nature trails and eco-tourism initiatives available within the reserve. These activities offer visitors the opportunity to explore the wilderness, observe wildlife in their natural habitat, and appreciate the pristine beauty of the surroundings. The office's staff can guide visitors in choosing the most suitable trails and ensure their safety during such excursions.7. Community Engagement and Outreach:The office actively engages with local communities residing near the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, recognizing the importance of their participation in conservation efforts. Through community outreach programs, the office promotes sustainable livelihood options, environmental education, and the benefits of eco-tourism. Such initiatives foster a sense of ownership and stewardship among the local population.8. Overall Experience:The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve Office serves as an essential gateway to the mesmerizing wildlife sanctuary. Its commitment to wildlife conservation, provision of information and permits, and engagement with visitors and local communities contribute to a comprehensive and fulfilling experience. The office plays a vital role in maintaining the ecological balance of the region while allowing visitors to appreciate its natural wonders.In conclusion, the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve Office is not just an administrative center but a hub of knowledge, conservation, and eco-tourism. Mudumalai Tiger Reserve is a captivating sanctuary located in the southern part of India. My visit to this pristine reserve left me in awe of its untouched natural beauty and the unique wildlife it harbors. The lush forests, rolling hills, and meandering streams create a perfect habitat for an array of flora and fauna.During my time at Mudumalai, I was fortunate to witness the grace and power of the magnificent tigers, as well as the playful antics of elephants and the elusive leopards. The guided safaris provided an excellent opportunity to observe these creatures in their natural environment, leaving me with unforgettable memories.The reserve's commitment to wildlife conservation and responsible tourism is commendable. The knowledgeable guides shared valuable insights about the ecosystem, emphasizing the importance of preserving this delicate balance.The serenity of Mudumalai is a true escape from the bustling city life. The sounds of chirping birds and rustling leaves added to the overall tranquility of the experience. The reserve also boasts a diverse range of bird species, making it a paradise for birdwatchers.However, it's worth noting that the safari routes can get crowded, which might hinder the chances of experiencing some rare sightings. Additionally, the accommodation options within the reserve are limited, and early booking is advisable.In conclusion, Mudumalai Tiger Reserve is a nature lover's haven, offering a unique chance to connect with wildlife and nature. "Serene Devotion and Spectacular Views: Murugan Temple in Ooty"During my recent visit to Ooty, I had the privilege of experiencing the tranquility and spirituality that the Murugan Temple offers. This place is undeniably a must-visit for anyone exploring Ooty, offering a unique blend of serenity, devotion, and breathtaking views.The centerpiece of the temple is a magnificent Murugan statue that stands tall at the top. The sight of this statue against the backdrop of the lush Ooty landscape is truly awe-inspiring. The intricacy and artistry of the statue reflect the devotion and craftsmanship that have gone into creating this place of worship.What truly captivated me, aside from the religious significance, was the peacefulness of the temple grounds. The serene ambiance seemed to envelop the entire area, making it an ideal spot for meditation, reflection, or simply finding solace amidst the chaos of daily life. The quietude of the surroundings allowed for a deep connection with the spiritual essence of the temple.To reach the temple, one needs to ascend approximately 70 steps. While this might seem like a daunting climb, the effort is truly worth it. As you ascend the steps, you'll find yourself leaving behind the bustling world below and entering a realm of peace and devotion. The journey to the temple is a metaphorical pilgrimage that prepares you for the spiritual experience that awaits at the top.The panoramic views from the temple grounds are a reward in themselves. As you stand in front of the deity, you're also treated to a mesmerizing vista of the Ooty landscape. The sight of the town and its surrounding hills is a reminder of the beauty of nature and the sanctity of the temple's location.In conclusion, the Murugan Temple in Ooty is an experience that transcends the boundaries of religion and offers a profound sense of calmness and connection. The grandeur of the Murugan statue, the peaceful atmosphere, and the stunning views make it an unforgettable visit. The climb to the temple is not just a physical journey, but a spiritual one that leads to a place of introspection and devotion. "Hawa Mahal" in Jaipur, India, is an absolute gem! This stunning monument is a must-visit when exploring the Pink City. The intricate architecture and unique design will leave you in awe.I visited Hawa Mahal during my trip to Jaipur, and it was an unforgettable experience. The pink sandstone facade with its countless windows and latticework is a true masterpiece. It’s like a beautiful honeycomb of history and culture.The entry fee for 'Hawa Mahal' Rs. 50 for Indians and Rs. 200 for foreigners. The opening hours from 9 AM to 4:30 PM are convenient for tourists.Inside, you’ll find a museum that sheds light on the rich history of Jaipur and the Mahal itself. The cool breeze flowing through the windows will make you understand why it’s called the “Palace of Winds.”Don’t forget your camera, as the Hawa Mahal provides some fantastic photo opportunities. I highly recommend a visit to this architectural marvel – it’s a visual delight and a true symbol of Jaipur’s heritage. 💗Thank you💗Visited on

The structure was built in 1799 by the Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh, grandson of Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh, the founder of the city of Jhunjhunu in the state of Rajasthan. He was so inspired by the unique structure of Khetri Mahal that he built this grand and historical palace.It was designed by Lal Chand Ustad. Its five-floor exterior is akin to a honeycomb with its 953 small windows called Jharokhas decorated with intricate latticework. The original intent of the lattice design was to allow royal ladies to observe everyday life and festivals celebrated in the street below without being seen. This architectural feature also allowed cool air from the Venturi effect to pass through, thus making the whole area more pleasant during the high temperatures in summer. Many people see the Hawa Mahal from the street view and think it is the front of the palace, but it is the back. This palace is a five-story pyramidal shaped monument that rises to about 50 feet (15 m). The top three floors of the structure have the width of a single room, while the first and second floors have patios in front of them. The front elevation, as seen from the street, is like a honeycomb with small portholes. Each porthole has miniature windows and carved sandstone grills, finials and domes. It gives the appearance of a mass of semi-octagonal bays, giving the monument its unique façade. The inner face on the back side of the building consists of chambers built with pillars and corridors with minimal ornamentation, and reach up to the top floor. The interior of the palace has been described as "having rooms of different coloured marbles, relieved by inlaid panels or gilding; while fountains adorn the centre of the courtyard.Visited on

Jantar Mantar in Jaipur, India, is an awe-inspiring testament to human ingenuity and scientific precision from ancient times. This extraordinary archaeological site offers a remarkable journey into the world of precise date and time calculation, zodiac sign prediction, and the measurement of earth angles, latitudes, and longitudes. What truly sets Jantar Mantar apart is the fact that these complex astronomical instruments were constructed with astonishing precision using nothing but stones and marbles, showcasing the incredible knowledge and engineering skills of its creators.Walking through Jantar Mantar feels like stepping back in time, as you explore the various massive instruments, each with a unique purpose. The immense sundials, the Ram Yantra, the Jai Prakash Yantra, and the Samrat Yantra, to name a few, are not only aesthetically pleasing but also serve as a reminder of humanity's ancient quest to understand and harness the cosmos. The ability of these instruments to accurately predict celestial events and measure the passage of time is a testament to the intellect and dedication of the astronomers and architects who designed them centuries ago. Visiting Jantar Mantar is a humbling experience that leaves you in awe of the advanced knowledge our ancestors possessed and their ability to craft timeless marvels out of stone. It's a place where history, science, and art converge to create an unforgettable and educational journey.Wait time
No waitJantar Mantar in Jaipur, India, is an awe-inspiring testament to human ingenuity and scientific precision from ancient times. This extraordinary archaeological site offers a remarkable journey into the world of precise date and time

मैने जंतर मंतर  सितंबर माह में विजिट किया था मेरा अनुभव बहुत बेहतरीन था ।जंतर मंतर के बारे में कुछ तथ्यजयपुर का जन्तर मन्तर सवाई जयसिंह द्वारा १७२४ से १७३४ के बीच निर्मित एक खगोलीय वेधशाला है। यह यूनेस्को के 'विश्व धरोहर सूची' में सम्मिलित है। इस वेधशाला में १४ प्रमुख यन्त्र हैं जो समय मापने, ग्रहण की भविष्यवाणी करने, किसी तारे की गति एवं स्थिति जानने, सौर मण्डल के ग्रहों के दिक्पात जानने आदि में सहायक हैं। इन यन्त्रों को देखने से पता चलता है कि भारत के लोगों को गणित एवं खगोलिकी के जटिल संकल्पनाओं (कॉंसेप्ट्स) का इतना गहन ज्ञान था कि वे इन संकल्पनाओं को एक 'शैक्षणिक वेधशाला' का रूप दे सके ताकि कोई भी उन्हें जान सके और उसका आनन्द ले सके।जंतर-मंत्र में स्थित यन्त्र आज भी सही सलामत अवस्था में है जिनके द्वारा हर साल वर्षा का पूर्वाभास तथा मौसम संबंधी जानकारियां एकत्रित की जाती है। मुख्य रूप से यंत्रों के सही सलामत होने के कारण ही यूनेस्को ने इसे विश्व विरासत का दर्जा दिया।जयपुर की वेधशाला में उपस्थित यंत्रों के द्वारा की गई गणनाओं के आधार पर आज भी यहां का पंचांग तैयार किया जाता है।I visited Jantar Mantar in the month of September and my experience was great.Some facts about Jantar MantarThe Jantar Mantar of Jaipur is an astronomical observatory built by Sawai Jai Singh between 1724 and 1734.  It is included in UNESCO's 'World Heritage List'.  There are 14 major instruments in this observatory, which are helpful in measuring time, predicting eclipse, knowing the position and movement of a star, knowing the declination of the planets of the solar system, etc.  Seeing these instruments shows that the people of India had such a deep knowledge of the complex concepts of mathematics and astronomy that they could make these concepts in the form of an 'educational observatory' so that anyone could know them and enjoy them.  Could takeThe yantra located in Jantar-Mantra is still in a safe condition, through which forecast of rain and meteorological information is collected every year.  UNESCO gave it the status of World Heritage mainly because of the well being of the instruments.Even today, the almanac is prepared here on the basis of the calculations made by the instruments present in the observatory of Jaipur.मैने जंतर मंतर  सितंबर माह में विजिट किया था मेरा अनुभव बहुत बेहतरीन था ।जंतर मंतर के बारे में कुछ तथ्य

Jantar mantar is one of the most important and wonderful monument built by Raja Jai Singh II.  There are total 5 Jantar Mantars in India- Jaipur, Delhi, Ujjain, Mathura and Varanasi.  But today only functional one is at Jaipur and i have heard that the one in Mathura is demolished.  The jantar mantar located in jaipur has 19 instruments.The beauty of this monument is that you can find exact local time with the help of Sun.  Hence it is sun based and would jot work during rainy season or in cloudy weather.  Astrologically it is important as today also many astrologers visit to find the exact position of nakshatra.  In older days this monument used to find local time and rashi and nakshatra of the new born, based on which the kundali was prepared.  It even tells the in which sun sign the child is born and it has all 12 sun signs for further predictions. The Jantar Mantar observatory in Jaipur constitutes the most significant and best preserved set of fixed monumental instruments built in India in the first half of the 18th century; some of them are the largest ever built in their categories. Jaipur, often referred to as the "Pink City" due to the distinct color of its historic buildings, is a city steeped in rich history and architectural splendor. Among the many landmarks that adorn this city, Jal Mahal stands out as a unique and captivating masterpiece. This review aims to delve into the intricate details, historical significance, architectural marvel, and overall experience of visiting Jal Mahal in Jaipur.**Introduction:**Jal Mahal, literally translated as the "Water Palace," is a breathtaking palace located in the midst of the Man Sagar Lake, just outside Jaipur. Its picturesque setting amidst the tranquil waters makes it a sight to behold and an essential stop for any traveler exploring the city. The palace is a five-story structure, with four levels submerged in the lake's waters during the monsoon season, giving the illusion of floating on the lake.**Historical Significance:**Built during the 18th century, during the reign of Maharaja Madho Singh I, Jal Mahal was intended to serve as a leisure retreat for the royal family and their entourage. The palace's location in the center of the lake allowed for privacy and exclusivity, creating an oasis of serenity amidst the bustling city.**Architectural Marvel:**Jal Mahal seamlessly blends elements of Rajput and Mughal architectural styles, resulting in a harmonious and captivating design. The palace's lower levels are made of red sandstone, a hallmark of Rajput architecture, while the upper floors exhibit delicate Mughal-style ornamental work. This unique fusion of styles showcases the cultural synthesis that was prevalent during that era.**Design and Layout:**The palace's design is a symphony of intricate details and thoughtful planning. The chhatris (domed pavilions) on the rooftop are adorned with lotus motifs and elegantly carved jali (lattice) screens, allowing for ventilation and a play of light and shadow. The chhatri on the central dome is particularly impressive, acting as the crown jewel of the palace's design.**Natural Integration:**What truly sets Jal Mahal apart is its remarkable integration with the natural environment. The palace seems to rise organically from the lake's waters, with its reflection creating a mesmerizing mirror image on the still surface. The surrounding Aravalli hills and the lush greenery further enhance the ethereal beauty of the scene.**Conservation Efforts:**Over the years, Jal Mahal faced significant challenges due to environmental degradation and neglect. The lake's pollution and the deterioration of the palace's structure raised concerns about its survival. However, conservation efforts have been initiated to restore the palace to its former glory. This includes cleaning the lake, restoring the architectural elements, and implementing measures to control pollution.**Visitor Experience:**Visiting Jal Mahal is a sensory delight. The journey to the palace involves a leisurely drive through the bustling city, followed by a tranquil boat ride on the lake to reach the palace. The view of the palace against the backdrop of the Aravalli hills during sunrise or sunset is a sight that leaves a lasting impression. The palace isn't open to the public for exploration inside, but its exterior beauty and the surrounding scenery offer ample opportunities for photography and contemplation.**Cultural Significance:**Jal Mahal stands as a testament to Jaipur's architectural prowess and cultural heritage. It embodies the opulence and refinement of the bygone era, offering a glimpse into the extravagant lifestyle of the royals. The palace's location also serves as a reminder of the Maharajas' connection with nature and their ability to create harmonious retreats within the urban landscape.**Conclusion:**In conclusion, Jal Mahal is more than just a palace; it's a living testament to the creative genius of the architects of its time. The Jal Mahal, or "Water Palace", is a five-story palace built in the middle of Man Sagar Lake in Jaipur, India. The palace is built entirely of red sandstone and is a combination of Rajput and Mughal architectural styles. The palace is one of the most popular attractions in Jaipur.The palace was originally intended to be a hunting lodge for the local king. However, in the 16th century, a severe drought caused the locals to build a dam, which created a lake that submerged the lower portions of the lodge. The palace's stone walls hold back millions of liters of water, and the specially designed lime mortar prevents water seepage into the palace. The palace's top floor is visible above the water, giving the impression that the palace is floating on the lake.The palace was commissioned by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II in the early 18th century.Visited on
Weekend

जलमहल राजस्थान की राजधानी जयपुर के मानसागर झील के मध्‍य स्थित प्रसिद्ध ऐतिहासिक महल है। अरावली पहाडिय़ों के गर्भ में स्थित यह महल झील के बीचों बीच होने के कारण 'आई बॉल' भी कहा जाता है। इसे 'रोमांटिक महल' के नाम से भी जाना जाता था। राजपूत राजा सवाई जयसिंह द्वारा निर्मित यह महल मध्‍यकालीन महलों की तरह मेहराबों, बुर्जो, छतरियों एवं सीढीदार जीनों से युक्‍त दुमंजिला और वर्गाकार रूप में निर्मित भवन है। जलमहल अब पक्षी अभ्‍यारण के रूप में भी विकसित हो रहा है। यहाँ की नर्सरी में 1 लाख से अधिक वृक्ष लगे हैं जहाँ राजस्थान के सबसे ऊँचे पेड़ पाए जाते हैं।जयपुर-आमेर मार्ग पर मानसागर झील के मध्‍य स्थित इस महल का निर्माण सवाई जय सिंह ने अश्वमेध यज्ञ के बाद अपनी रानियों और पंडित के साथ स्‍नान के लिए करवाया था। इस महल के निर्माण से पहले मानसिंह ने जयपुर की जलापूर्ति हेतु गर्भावती नदी पर बांध बनवाकर मानसागर झील का निर्माण करवाया।[2] इसका निर्माण 1699 में हुआ था। इसके निर्माण के लिए राजपूत शैली से तैयार की गई नौकाओं की मदद ली गई थी। राजा इस महल को अपनी रानी के साथ ख़ास वक्‍त बिताने के लिए इस्‍तेमाल करते थे। वे इसका प्रयोग राजसी उत्सवों पर भी करते थे।इस झील के पास स्ट्रीट मार्केट है जहा आप यहां की ट्रेडिशनल चीजे खरीद सकते है।।Jalmahal is a famous historical palace located in the middle of Mansagar Lake in Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan.  Situated in the heart of the Aravalli Hills, this palace is also known as 'Eye Ball' due to its location in the middle of the lake.  It was also known as 'Romantic Palace'.  Built by Rajput King Sawai Jai Singh, this palace is a double-storeyed and square-shaped building with arches, bastions, umbrellas and staircases like medieval palaces.  Jalmahal is now being developed as a bird sanctuary as well.  There are more than 1 lakh trees planted in the nursery where the tallest trees of Rajasthan are found.Situated in the middle of Mansagar Lake on the Jaipur-Amer road, this palace was built by Sawai Jai Singh for taking a bath with his queens and priest after the Ashwamedha Yagya.  Before the construction of this palace, Mansingh constructed the Mansagar lake by building a dam on the Garbhavati river for the water supply of Jaipur. [2] It was constructed in 1699.  For its construction, the help of Rajput-style boats was taken.  The king used this palace to spend special time with his queen.  They also used it on royal festivals.There is a street market near this lake where you can buy traditional things here.Visited on

Karla Caves are one of the earliest and oldest examples of well-preserved, richly decorated rock-cut shrines in India and represent the pinnacle of Indian rock-cut architecture at the time, that our country is so proud of. These caves are comparable in splendour to Ajanta and Ellora.It is located in the village of Karli, 10 KM from Lonavla, a hill station in Maharashtra, constructed during Satavahana's rule, between the 2nd century AD to the 5th century AD, by the Buddhist monks for meditation and worship.These well-known Buddhist rock-cut excavations consists of 16 caves that has one of the largest Caitya Griha in India, known as the Great Chaitya, with its apsidal chamber extending 124 feet into it, and a barrel-vaulted roof 46 feet high.  The chaitya griha is created with an amalgamation of timber and stone.  This chamber consists of a broad central nave with two narrow aisles on either side by a row of fifteen octagonal pillars.The entrance of the Karla Caves is gorgeous. You need to show the entry ticket at the gate. The strong rock cut representation of three Lion Pillars found at the entrance of the cave looks magnificent.There is a sculpture of Buddha preaching seated on a lion-supported throne, which has splendid carvings of three elephants. The pillars are adorned with motifs of elephants, men and riding women.There are Elephant Heads carved out of single stone with minute detailing. There are a few images and structures that are sadly broken by humans, yet they look exotic as ever.Entering the cave viharas through the little patch of tiny rock cut stairs is bit of a challenge, steps inside the cave are wet with rainwater and dark without light, one needs a torch. However, windows have also been built so that sunlight is allowed to penetrate in the hall. The door of the viharas are closed with barriers and prevented from entering.These caves are located just 3 km away from the main road amidst green surroundings.There are parking available uphill at the base of the cave but not enough to support the crowd on a Sunday. Road is steep and narrow with breathtaking view of the mountain and the valley. We drove up but there was a long jam closer to the base. We had to reverse slowly and park the vehicle halfway down by the road in a little broader space.There is also a waterfall near the cave where tourists can refresh themselves with a dip.Once you reach the base, it takes nearly 20 minutes to climb up the steep way approx. 500 steps to the Karla caves. The Aai Ekveera temple has been built recently at the entrance using pillars from the Buddhist period sharing the same premises.Visiting hour: 8:30 am to 5:00 pm on all days of the week.Entry fees is INR 5 for Indian citizens and INR 100 for foreigners. Tender exact change. It works on Cash only.Caves, Lohagad and Visapur forts are not far from these caves.Visited on
Weekend

To start with a disclaimer – we reached here by 4pm and already has a long day. It’s a wonderful trek with good views, but nothing you cannot see from other places we went to.The house of George Everest & the Observatory from where they measured heights of various mountains including Mt. Everest is newly renovated but not open to the public, which is a shame as the climb upto this place itself is a very steep 1.2km trek (which took us 30 minutes). Another 900m higher from the base takes you to a higher point from house to have better view – but we did not / could not do it. it would have taken another 20-30 minutes for the sameThere are no toilet facilities here. There is just 1 buggy to take us to the house and is always full so we couldn't avail. Carry a water bottle, stick, sunglasses, and sun cream while going for the trek.To start with a disclaimer – we reached here by 4pm and already has a long day. It’s a wonderful trek with good views, but nothing you cannot see from other places we went to.

Embarking on a bike ride to Shri Kashi Vishwanath Temple from Belagavi was a thrilling and spiritually enriching journey. The scenic route offered a perfect blend of adventure and devotion, making it an unforgettable experience.The ride began with the morning sun casting its golden rays on the open road, creating a sense of freedom and excitement. The lush greenery and picturesque landscapes along the way added to the charm of the journey, making each mile a visual delight.As we cruised through quaint villages and vibrant towns, we encountered the rich culture and traditions of the region. The locals were warm and welcoming, adding a sense of hospitality to our bike ride.The spiritual experience of offering prayers at the temple was profound and fulfilling. The divine energy within the temple grounds was palpable, leaving a lasting impression on our souls.Overall, the bike ride to Shri Kashi Vishwanath Temple from Belagavi was a perfect blend of adventure, scenic beauty, and spiritual connection. It not only strengthened our bond with nature and culture but also deepened our faith. This pilgrimage on two wheels will remain etched in our hearts as one of the most cherished memories of a lifetime.Embarking on a bike ride to Shri Kashi Vishwanath Temple from Belagavi was a thrilling and spiritually enriching journey. The scenic route offered a perfect blend of adventure and devotion, making it an unforgettable experience.

The ghat itself is an architectural and artistic marvel, with elaborate carvings and brilliant colours covering every surface. As locals and visitors alike converge to see the daily Ganga aarti ceremony, the excitement of the throng is contagious. The sight of hundreds of lamps being lit and offered to the river is incredibly hypnotic. DashaSwamedh Ghat in Varanasi is a must-visit for its awe-inspiring grandeur and beauty, with ornate steps leading to the Ganges River. The daily Ganga Aarti ceremony is a spiritual spectacle, featuring priests, mantras, and music, leaving you with a profound sense of peace. People-watching here is fascinating, from pilgrims taking holy dips to lively street vendors. While it can get crowded, it adds to the charm and liveliness of the place.For a quieter experience, consider visiting during early morning or early evening hours.In conclusion, DashaSwamedh Ghat encapsulates the spiritual, cultural, and historical essence of Varanasi, leaving you with cherished memories and a deep appreciation for life along the Ganges.Visited on

Tulsi #Manas #Mandir is a kind of Must Visit temple in Banaras aka Varanasi aka Kashi. Normally there is no entry fees for the temple and Jhhanki. However, to see the puppet show there is a nominal entry fees of ₹10. #children as well as adults both can enjoy the show.Whole temple is made up of white Marble and complete Ramcharit Manas is written on the walls of the temple. Nestled along the banks of the holy Ganges River in the spiritual city of Varanasi, Manikarnika Ghat stands as a timeless symbol of life, death, and rebirth in Hinduism. This sacred site has drawn pilgrims, seekers, and curious travelers for centuries, and my recent visit left an indelible mark on my soul. Join me as I share my experiences and insights from my visit to the iconic Manikarnika Ghat.A Glimpse into History:Manikarnika Ghat is not just a place; it's a profound chapter in the rich history of Varanasi. Legends say that it was here that Lord Shiva's earring (Manikarnika) fell, hence the name. The ghat is also associated with the Great Cremation Ground, where Hindus believe that cremating the deceased leads to liberation from the cycle of reincarnation. As I approached, I was struck by the fusion of spirituality and mortality that permeates the air.The Rituals and Ceremonies:The heart of Manikarnika Ghat beats with the rhythm of rituals and ceremonies. I witnessed the continuous cremation pyres, each telling a story of a life lived and a soul on its journey to moksha (liberation). The sight was intense and thought-provoking, a reminder of the impermanence of life. The locals explained the rituals with reverence and grace, sharing their deep-rooted beliefs.The Aura of Spirituality:Walking through the labyrinthine alleys leading to the ghat, I was enveloped by the aura of spirituality. Sadhus and pilgrims clad in saffron robes wandered the streets, offering blessings and sharing their wisdom. The resonance of bells, the aroma of incense, and the constant chants created an otherworldly atmosphere that transported me to a realm beyond the physical.A Lesson in Acceptance:Manikarnika Ghat taught me the importance of embracing the inevitable cycle of life and death. It's a place where one can reflect on the impermanence of existence and the necessity of letting go. The acceptance of death as an integral part of life is a lesson that Manikarnika Ghat imparts with unparalleled depth.Conclusion:My visit to Manikarnika Ghat was a journey into the heart of spirituality, mortality, and the human experience. It's a place where life and death dance together in a sacred harmony that challenges our perception of the world. While it may not be an easy visit for everyone, it is undoubtedly a transformative one. Manikarnika Ghat stands as a timeless testament to the profound mysteries of existence, inviting all who come to contemplate the circle of life and death.In the end, my journey to Manikarnika Ghat left me with a sense of humility and a deep appreciation for the beauty and complexity of life. It's a destination that will forever remain etched in my memory, a place where the soul is stirred and the spirit finds solace.Nestled along the banks of the holy Ganges River in the spiritual city of Varanasi, Manikarnika Ghat stands as a timeless symbol of life, death, and rebirth in Hinduism. This sacred site has drawn pilgrims, seekers, and curious travelers

Manikarnika Ghat (Hindi: मणिकर्णिका घाट) is one of the holiest[1] cremation grounds among the sacred riverfronts (ghats), located on the Ganges, in the city of Varanasi in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. In Hinduism, death is considered a gateway to another life marked by the result of one's karma. It is believed that a human's soul attains moksha, and hence breaks the cycle of rebirth when cremated here.[2]The Manikarnika Ghat is flanked by the Dashashwamedh Ghat and the Scindia Ghat. It is situated in Varanasi, Kashi region, IndiaThe Manikarnika Ghat is one of the oldest ghats in Varanasi. It is mentioned in a Gupta inscription of 5th century.[4] It is revered in Hindu religion. When Mata Sati (Adi Shakti) sacrificed her life and set her body ablaze after Raja Daksh Prajapati (one of the sons of Lord Brahma) tried to humiliate Lord Shiva in a Yagya practiced by Daksh, Lord Shiva took her burning body to the Himalaya. On seeing the unending sorrow of Lord Shiva, Vishnu sent the Divine chakra to cut the body into 51 parts, which then fell to earth. These are called "Ekannya Shaktipeeth". Lord Shiva established Shakti Peeth wherever Sati's body had fallen. Mata Sati's ear ornament fell at Manikarnika Ghat.Manikarnika Ghat (Hindi: मणिकर्णिका घाट) is one of the holiest[1] cremation grounds among the sacred riverfronts (ghats), located on the Ganges, in the city of Varanasi in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. Manikarnika Ghat is one of the most important ghats in Varanasi. It is located on the banks of the Ganges River and is a major cremation ground. Hindus believe that being cremated at Manikarnika Ghat will help them achieve moksha, or liberation from the cycle of reincarnation.Manikarnika ghat VaranasiThe ghat is said to have been named after the earring of Parvati, the wife of Shiva, which fell into the Ganges River at this spot. It is also said that the ashes of Vishnu, one of the three main gods of Hinduism, were scattered here.The ghat is a busy place, with cremations taking place around the clock. The bodies of the dead are brought to the ghat on bamboo stretchers and are cremated on wood pyres. The ashes of the dead are then scattered in the Ganges River.Manikarnika Ghat is a fascinating place to visit, but it can also be a sobering one. It is a reminder of the cycle of life and death, and of the importance of living a good life.Manikarnika Ghat is one of the most important ghats in Varanasi. Varanasi, also known as Banaras, stands as one of the world's oldest inhabited cities and holds significant religious importance in India. Nestled along the banks of the revered river Ganges, it boasts a multitude of Ghats, which are a defining feature of the city's rich cultural heritage. With approximately 80 Ghats in Varanasi, each serving a distinct purpose, they are central to the daily lives of its inhabitants.A visit to the Varanasi Ghats offers an enchanting glimpse into the ancient traditions and customs of the city. Vibrant and bustling with activity, the Ghats witness locals engaging in various religious rituals and ceremonies. Among them, the Ganga Aarti held at the Dashashwamedh Ghat every evening is particularly renowned. This mesmerizing ritual, performed by priests, involves fire, flowers, and incense, leaving an indelible impression on those fortunate enough to witness it.Furthermore, the Ghats attract tourists seeking to embark on a boat ride along the majestic Ganges River. Hiring a boat allows visitors to leisurely traverse the waters, admiring the scenic vistas of the Ghats and the city's captivating skyline. Along the journey, one encounters the iconic Manikarnika Ghat, where cremation rituals are conducted. Revered as the holiest and most auspicious site for Hindu cremations, it is believed that the ashes released here provide liberation from the cycle of rebirth and death.In essence, exploring the Varanasi Ghats is an essential part of any visit to India. Imbued with beauty, tradition, and spirituality, they offer a profound insight into the ancient roots of the city. From witnessing breathtaking rituals to enjoying serene boat rides on the Ganges River, visitors can immerse themselves in the soul-stirring ambiance of Varanasi's Ghats.Varanasi, also known as Banaras, stands as one of the world's oldest inhabited cities and holds significant religious importance in India. Manikarnika Ghat is one the famous & oldest ghats in Varanasi, UP. It is mentioned in a Gupta inscription of 5th century. According to the belief, when Shiva Parvati was observing the pond, the gem of Parvati's ear fell in Chakrapushkarni. It was named Manikarnika because of the fall of Parvati's ear gem. Presently, this ghat of Kashi is famous for both pilgrimage & cremation ground. In all there are 52 Shakti Peethas all over India, and Manikarnika Ghat is one of them, as Sati's earrings fell at this spot.Every day, more than 300 bodies are cremated in this ghat.Hindu mythology teaches that the ghat is especially sacred and that people cremated there receive moksha. The well at the ghat is called Manikarnika Kund and was built by Lord Vishnu. The Manikarnika shrine is an important place of worship for Shaktism sect of Hinduism. It is near to the Kashi Vishwanath Temple. The Shakti of Manikarnika is addressed as Vishalakshi & Manikarni.Manikarnika Ghat is one the famous & oldest ghats in Varanasi, UP. The Gateway of India, situated in Mumbai, is a splendid architectural marvel that holds a significant place in India's history and culture. Standing proudly on the shores of the Arabian Sea, it is a symbol of India's rich colonial past and enduring heritage.Built in 1924, the Gateway of India exudes grandeur and elegance. Its towering arch, crafted in a blend of Indo-Saracenic and Muslim architectural styles, is a mesmerizing sight. The yellow basalt structure is adorned with intricate latticework, adding to its charm.Beyond its aesthetic appeal, the Gateway of India has witnessed pivotal moments in India's history. It served as the exit point for British dignitaries during colonial rule and later as a site for the departure of the last British troops in 1948, marking India's independence.Today, it stands as a bustling hub for locals and tourists alike. Visitors can stroll along the waterfront, savor street food, and relish panoramic views of the Arabian Sea. The surrounding area is abuzz with activity, making it a must-visit destination in Mumbai.In summary, the Gateway of India is not just an architectural gem but also a living testament to India's journey through history. Its enduring presence continues to make it a captivating symbol of the nation's past and present.The Gateway of India, situated in Mumbai, is a splendid architectural marvel that holds a significant place in India's history and culture. The Siddhivinayak Temple in Mumbai is a revered religious landmark that draws devotees and visitors alike. Known for its magnificent architecture and spiritual significance, the temple exudes a sense of tranquility amidst the bustling city. The main deity, Lord Ganesha, is believed to grant blessings and fulfill wishes, resulting in a constant stream of devotees seeking his grace.The temple's inner sanctum houses a stunning idol of Lord Ganesha, carved from a single black stone. The intricately designed entrance and beautifully adorned surroundings contribute to the temple's vibrant atmosphere. While the temple can get crowded, the faith and devotion of the visitors create a unique aura of devotion.Visiting the Siddhivinayak Temple provides an opportunity to experience Mumbai's cultural and religious richness. However, due to its popularity, it's advisable to plan a visit during off-peak hours to fully appreciate the spiritual ambiance and avoid long waiting times.Visited on

Shri Siddhivinayak Temple is one of the most popular and revered Hindu temples in Mumbai, India. It is dedicated to Lord Ganesha, the remover of obstacles and the bestower of success. The temple is located in the Prabhadevi neighborhood of Mumbai and is easily accessible by public transportation.The temple was built in the early 19th century and has since become a major pilgrimage site for Hindus from all over India and the world. The temple is known for its powerful deity and its miraculous powers. Devotees often visit the temple to pray for success in their careers, studies, and personal lives.The temple is a beautiful structure with white marble walls and intricate carvings. The main sanctum sanctorum houses the idol of Lord Ganesha, which is made of black stone. The idol is adorned with gold and precious jewels.The temple complex also includes a number of other shrines, including a Hanuman temple and a Navagraha temple. The temple is well-maintained and clean. The staff is friendly and helpful.Visiting Shri Siddhivinayak Temple is a truly spiritual experience. The temple is a place where people from all walks of life come to pray for their wishes to be fulfilled. The atmosphere is peaceful and serene, and the presence of Lord Ganesha can be felt everywhere.Beautiful temple with a powerful deityWell-maintained and cleanFriendly and helpful staffPeaceful and serene atmosphereA truly spiritual experienceShri Siddhivinayak Temple is a must-visit for anyone visiting Mumbai. It is a place where you can experience the true essence of Hindu faith and culture.Wait time
1 hr+

Reservation recommended

वक्रतुण्ड महाकाय, सूर्यकोटि समप्रभ ।निर्विघ्नं कुरु मे देव, सर्वकार्येषु सर्वदा ॥Devoting completely in the feet of Lord Ganesha, I would like to mention my apology to all the devotees.My review is about the Management Committee and the Security staff of this temple who is managing the crowd in the Garbh Griha. You all are worst. You are treating Ganpatti Bappa as business. You people are also considering yourself bigger personality than devotees and the Ganpati Bappa himself. I imagine, very soon, Ganpati Bappa is going to punish you all for this unethical management and behavior. Your management inside and outside "Garbha Griha" is horrible.My mentioning here is my true experience with this temple which was really horrible. So, it's a humble request to all the devotees to go through my words first before coming to a conclusion. Obviously my words are going to justify my ratings and reviews for this temple.I was in the temple on the 7th day of the Ganpati Pooja. I reached in the temple with my family at around 8:45 PM when sufficient crowd was already in queue. The queue was not too long and also not too short. We opted to go in the 100/- Rs. paid line. We took the ticket and reached near to the Garbh Griha.The actual incident started at that moment. At the gate both, paid and non-paid queues were merged. People were rushing for the darshan of Bappa. They were ready to insult women, also were looking ready to crush small kids. Only their moto was to collect the  bappa maximum as they can. Facing all the chalenges, we reached near for darshan, surrendered our prashad and pushp to the pandit jee. It was hardly a second or two, when the security personal started throwing us out of the Garbh Grih. Luckily I was third. So, before me he pushed a lady and a gents. That lady became very angry and she was about to "offer a slap" to that security personal because he pushed at her breast. This was witnessed by my wife.He was saved because continuously he was pushing the people, so as she turned back she observed three men and a lady in between her and the security personal. Then she shouted with her ease. And this way that security was saved.In all this incident, we were not able to see Ganpati Bappa for a moment at least. We ignored the incident, and thought to take blessings from outside the Garbha Griha. But we were wrong, another security personal was standing who was more rude than the first one. Immediately we requested him just to allow for a second to have a look for Ganpati Bappa. But he was not ready to listen a single word.Finally, on this very important day, we remembered Ganpati Bappa in our heart and surrendered ourselves because we tried our best for the blessings."Observation for 100/- Queue" :Useless to pay, because near to "Garbha Griha", they merge all free and paid line together. Both the queues take almost same time."Observation inside the Gabha Griha":Security personal are rude enough and do misconduct with women too when they observe rush."Observation for Darshan":Security inside the Garbh Griha are in extra hurry irrespective of the crowd. They are ready to throw everyone out without delay as they enter."Peace in The Temple":It can be best defined in the terms of business."And at the Last Again":वक्रतुण्ड महाकाय, सूर्यकोटि समप्रभ ।निर्विघ्नं कुरु मे देव, सर्वकार्येषु सर्वदा ॥Visited on

One of the unique features of the Haji Ali Dargah is its location on the islet, which gets submerged during high tide, making it accessible only during low tide. This adds to the mystique and charm of the shrine.Apart from its religious significance, the Haji Ali Dargah is also a popular tourist attraction, drawing visitors with its serene ambiance, stunning views of the Arabian Sea, and the spiritual aura surrounding the place.One of the unique features of the Haji Ali Dargah is its location on the islet, which gets submerged during high tide, making it accessible only during low tide. This adds to the mystique and charm of the shrine.

An exquisite example of Indo-Islamic Architecture, associated with legends about doomed lovers, the dargah contains the tomb of Haji Ali Shah Bukhari. Bukhari was a Sufi saint and a wealthy merchant from Uzbekistan. Near the heart of the city proper, the dargah is one of the most recognisable landmarks of Mumbai.

Beautiful place built by Rashtrakutas. We went there by taking the ferry from Gateway of India. 1 hour boat ride. After taking the boat, there is a toy train to the foot of the caves after which we would have to climb the stairs. Climbing the stairs was very difficult since it was very steep. Wear shoes because there is a lot to walk. If you are genuinely interested in history, then this is the right place for you. For us, we were a little bored since the caves were all repetitive and looked the same, nothing to see inside. Just plain caves with empty rooms. 2-3 hours sufficient to see around. Beware of monkeys. They are everywhere and try to steal your food and belongings. There is an entry fee of 40 and an extra ₹5 for tax. Closing time is 5:30 after which there is no boat from the caves to Gateway. Plenty of restaurants nearby. Carry a water bottle and cap since you'll get dehydrated and tired from all the walking. Overall, a different and new experience.Visited on

Uttar Pradesh, the Land of The Taj is rich in its cultural heritage and has always been a prominent arena of politics since the ancient times. Agra, the City of The Taj and once the capital of the Mughal Empire during the 16th through the early 18th centuries, enjoys a close proximity to the National Capital City of New Delhi.Tourists from all over the world visit Agra to make a pilgrimage to Taj Mahal, India’s most famous architectural wonder, in a land where magnificent temples and edifices abound to remind visitors about the rich civilization of a country that is slowly but surely lifting itself into an industrialized society as well.Taj Mahal means "Crown Palace" and is in fact the most well preserved and architecturally beautiful tomb in the world. The English poet, Sir Edwin Arnold has described The Taj as "Not a piece of architecture, as other buildings are, but the proud passions of an emperor’s love wrought in living stones."Uttar Pradesh, the Land of The Taj is rich in its cultural heritage and has always been a prominent arena of politics since the ancient times. The Taj Nature Walk is an under-rated gem in Agra. It consists of forest land, with hiking trails among dense wood, packed with a good deal of birds (not any that I could identify). But a fine place to walk around (especially in the mild December sunshine) and enjoying the bird calls drifting in the midst of trees. There are designated look out points from where the Taj can be well seen, including benches to park oneself. I would say one hour is the bare minimum. But there are some off-beat paths that go deeper into the woods. There are washrooms in the main area, including an open lawn, ideal for picnics and even some swings for the children. It is interesting that this nature spot is so close to the Taj and easily accessible from the Taj East Gate Road. I confess the entry ticket is no longer in my memory but it was completely worth what this place has to offer. Bonus point was that it was not crowded, unlike the hordes of visitors (local and international) at the Taj Mahal.The Taj Nature Walk is an under-rated gem in Agra. अकबर का मकबरा, आगरा के सिकंदरा में स्थित है, और माना जाता है कि इसका निर्माण 17वीं शताब्दी में अकबर ने स्वयं करवाया था। हालांकि इस मकबरे की संपूर्ण सरंचना को अकबर के बेटे ने पूरा किया। यह मकबरा मुगलकालीन वास्तुकला का अनूठा उदाहरण है। आगर भ्रमण पर निकले पर्यटक इस प्राचीन संरचना को देखना पसंद करते हैं। खासकर दीवारों की गई बारीक नक्काशी आगंतुकों को काफी ज्यादा प्रभावित करती है। मकबरे का हर एक कोना देखने लायक है। यहां मौजूद मेहरावे और मीनारे कारीगर की दक्षता को भली भांति प्रदर्शित करती हैं। वैसे इस मकबरे से एक ऐसा रहस्य भी जुड़ा है, जिसके बारे में अधिकांश लोगों को नहीं पता। क्या आप जानते हैं भले ही यह अकबर का मकबरा है, लेकिन इस मकबरे में अकबर की अस्थियां मौजूद नहीं है। इसके पीछे की भी एक अनकही कहानी जुड़ी है। इतिहास से जुड़े पन्नों के मुताबिक यह मकबरा कभी किसी जाट शासक द्वारा लूटा गया था, जिसने अकबर की कब्र से उसकी अस्थियां निकालकर आगरे की गलियां में घूमाईं थी, क्योंकि वो पिता का बदला लेना चाहता था। यह अकबर से जुड़ा एक महत्वपूर्ण स्थल आपको यहां जरूर आना चाहिए।Visited on

Akbar's Tomb is located in Sikandra, Agra, and is believed to have been built by Akbar himself in the 17th century. However, the entire structure of this tomb was completed by Akbar's son. This tomb is a unique example of Mughal architecture. Tourists visiting Agar like to see this ancient structure. Especially the intricate carvings on the walls impress the visitors a lot. Every corner of the tomb is worth seeing. The arches and minarets present here clearly demonstrate the skill of the artisan. Well, there is a mystery associated with this tomb, which most of the people do not know about. Do you know that even though this is Akbar's tomb, Akbar's ashes are not present in this tomb. There is an untold story behind this too. According to the pages related to history, this tomb was once looted by a Jat ruler, who took out the ashes of Akbar from his tomb and roamed around in the streets of Agra, because he wanted to take revenge of his father. You must visit this important place associated with Akbar.Visited on
Weekend

Howrah Bridge is known as the pride of West Bengal and specifically of Kolkata. This bridge is also known as the Gateway of Kolkata was inaugurated in 1943. It is 80 years old bridge that connects the cities of Howrah and Kolkata and runs a length of 405 metres with a width of 21.6 metres.Howrah Bridge is a Cantilever Bridge built over the Hooghly River in West Bengal. It is considered to be one of the longest Cantilever Bridges in the world and also known as Rabindra Setu, in 1965 it was renamed Rabindra Setu in the name of the great Bengali poet Rabindranath Tagore. It carries around 100,000 vehicles and countless pedestrians daily.One of the interesting facts of the Howrah Bridge was constructed without using any bolts or nuts. it was the third-longest cantilever bridge in the world at the beginning of its construction but currently, it is the sixth-longest. One of the fact is that 26,500 tonnes steel was utilised for its construction produced by Tata Steel.You know what, "Tram" was the first vehicle to cross the Howrah Bridge. According to the census of 1946, more than 27,400 vehicles, 2997 cattle, and almost 121,100 pedestrians travelled through the bridge daily and this number has outgrown over the course of time. In 1993 Trams were prohibited from using the bridge because they could not take the escalating traffic and footfall.If you are near the Howrah Bridge, you must visit it once. The Howrah Bridge night view is breathtaking as it gets lights up and makes you fall in love with this magnificent beauty.Howrah Bridge is known as the pride of West Bengal and specifically of Kolkata. Fort William is a fort in Hastings, Calcutta. It was built during the early years of the Bengal Presidency of British India. It sits on the eastern banks of the Hooghly River, the major distributary of the River Ganges. One of Kolkata's most enduring Raj-era edifices, it extends over an area of 70.9 hectares. The fort was named after King William III. In front of the Fort is the Maidan, the largest park in the country. An internal guard room became the Black Hole of Calcutta. Today it is the Headquarters of Eastern Command of the Indian Army.Fort William is a fort in Hastings, Calcutta. It was built during the early years of the Bengal Presidency of British India. You can see the best view of entire Jodhpur from Mehrangarh Fort. The wall of this fort extends for 10 kilometers and the height of the wall ranges from 20 feet to 120 feet. At the same time, the width of the wall ranges from 12 feet to 70 feet.There are 7 gates in Mehrangarh Fort, which are called Pol. One of these poles was built by Maharaja Mansingh of Jaipur in 1806 to celebrate the victory in the war between Jaipur and Bikaner. Mehrangarh Museum is still a witness, in which it is kept The costumes of kings and emperors and their weapons. Also, things related to their lifestyle are still present here…. Located right in the middle of Jodhpur city of Rajasthan, this fort is built at a height of about 125 meters. The foundation of this fort was laid by Rao Jodha in the 15th century, but its construction work was completed by Maharaj Jaswant Singh.मेहरानगढ़ किले से पूरे जोधपुर का बेहतरीन नजारा आप देख सकते हैं. इस फोर्ट की दीवार 10 किलोमीटर तक फैली है और दीवार की ऊंचाई 20 फीट से 120 फीट तक है. वहीं, दीवार की चौड़ाई 12 फीट से 70 फीट तक है....मेहरानगढ़ फोर्ट में 7 दरवाजे हैं, जिन्हें पोल कहा जाता है. इन में से एक पोल का निर्माण जयपुर के महाराजा मानसिंह ने सन् 1806 में जयपुर और बीकानेर के युद्ध में मिली जीत की खुशी में बनवाया था. मेहरानगढ़ म्यूजियम आज भी गवाह है, जिसमें रखे हैं राजा-महाराजाओं की पोशाकें और उनके हथियार. साथ ही, उनके रहन-सहन से जुड़ी चीजें आज भी यहां मौजूद हैं....। राजस्थान के जोधपुर शहर के ठीक बीचों-बीच स्थित यह किला करीब 125 मीटर की ऊंचाई पर बना है। 15वीं शताब्दी में इस किले की नींव राव जोधा ने रखी थी, लेकिन इसके निर्माण का कार्य महाराज जसवंत सिंह ने पूरा किया।Wait time

place_name: Gayatri Shaktipeeth Shree Chamunda Mata Temple
review: The Chamunda Mata Temple in Jodhpur is the temple of Chamunda Devi, the presiding deity of the royal family. It is situated in the southern part of Mehrangarh Fort. Rao Jodha, the founder of the city of Jodhpur, bought an idol of his favorite goddess Chamunda from the old capital of Mandore in 1460. He had installed the idol of Goddess Chamunda in the Mehrangarh Fort and since then Chamunda had become the deity here. place_name: Gayatri Shaktipeeth Shree Chamunda Mata Temple
review: जब मैं जौधपुर किला देखने गया तब मैं इस मंदिर को भी देख कर आया। जोधपुर का चामुंडा माता मंदिर, चामुंडा देवी का मंदिर है,  जो शाही परिवार के इष्ट देवी है। यह मेहरानगढ़ किले के दक्षिणी भाग में स्थित है। जोधपुर शहर के संस्थापक राव जोधा ने 1460 में मंदोरे की पुरानी राजधानी से अपनी प्रिय देवी चामुंडा की मूर्ति खरीदी थी। उन्होंने मेहरानगढ़ किले में चामुंडा देवी की मूर्ति को स्थापित किया था और तब से चामुंडा यहाँ देवी बन गयी थी। जोधपुर शहर के बाहर और अंदर से आने वाले लोगो द्वारा पूजा की जाती है, दशहरा के समय, किला लोगों और भक्तों से बहर जाता है। मैंने राजस्थान सामान्य ज्ञान किताबों में पढ़ा है किमेहरानगढ़ किले जोधपुर में स्थित, मंदिर राव जोधा द्वारा उस समय बनाया गया था जब वह किले का निर्माण कर रहे थे। वह पहाड़ी जहां उन्होंने इस किले का निर्माण करने के लिए चुना था वह हरमीत भट्ट द्वारा अधिकृत किया गया था | उनको वह से निकल दिया दिया था जिस कारण उन्होंने राजा को  श्राप दिया कि उनके किले में हमेशा पानी की कमी रहेगी।संत ने इस श्राप से बचने के लिए  और उससे लोगों की रक्षा करने  के लिए किले के अंदर चामुंडा माता का मंदिर बनाया। और तभी से देवी चामुंडा राजपूतों की मुख्य देवी है।चामुंडा माता मंदिर, जोधपुर तक कैसे जाएरोड से : चामुंडा माता मंदिर मेहरानगढ़ किले में जोधपुर शहर के बाहरी इलाके पर स्थित है। जहाँ आसानी से बस या टैक्सी द्वारा पहुंचा सकता है।रेल द्वारा : चामुंडा माता मंदिर निकटतम जोधपुर रेलवे स्टेशन से बड़े शहरों जैसे दिल्ली, आगरा, मुंबई, चेन्नई, बीकानेर, जोधपुर, जयपुर, अहमदाबाद के रेलवे स्टेशनों से जुड़ा हुआ है।हवाई यात्रा द्वारा : चामुंडा माता मंदिर निकटतम जोधपुर हवाई अड्डे (6 किमी ) से पहुंचा जा सकता है जो अच्छी तरह से दिल्ली, मुंबई के लिए नियमित डोमेस्टिक उड़ानों से जुड़ा हुआ है।जब मैं जौधपुर किला देखने गया तब मैं इस मंदिर को भी देख कर आया। जोधपुर का चामुंडा माता मंदिर, चामुंडा देवी का मंदिर है,  जो शाही परिवार के इष्ट देवी है। यह मेहरानगढ़ किले के दक्षिणी भाग में स्थित है। जोधपुर शहर के संस्थापक राव जोधा ने 1460

place_name: Gayatri Shaktipeeth Shree Chamunda Mata Temple
review: When I went to see Jodhpur Fort, I also saw this temple. Chamunda Mata Temple in Jodhpur is the temple of Chamunda Devi, the favored goddess of the royal family. It is situated in the southern part of Mehrangarh Fort. Rao Jodha, the founder of the city of Jodhpur, purchased the statue of his favorite goddess Chamunda from the old capital of Mandore in 1460. He installed the idol of Chamunda Devi in ​​Mehrangarh Fort and since then Chamunda had become a goddess here. Worshiped by people coming from inside and outside Jodhpur city, during the time of Dussehra, the fort is overflowing with people and devotees. I have read in Rajasthan general knowledge books thatLocated in the Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur, the temple was built by Rao Jodha when he was building the fort. The hill where he chose to build this fort was occupied by Harmeet Bhatt. He was thrown out of it due to which he cursed the king that there would always be shortage of water in his fort.To avoid this curse and to protect the people from it, the saint built the temple of Chamunda Mata inside the fort. And since then Goddess Chamunda is the main goddess of Rajputs.How to reach Chamunda Mata Temple, JodhpurBy Road: Chamunda Mata Temple is located on the outskirts of Jodhpur city in the Mehrangarh Fort. Where one can easily reach by bus or taxi.By Rail: Chamunda Mata Temple is connected to the railway stations of big cities like Delhi, Agra, Mumbai, Chennai, Bikaner, Jodhpur, Jaipur, Ahmedabad from the nearest Jodhpur Railway Station.By Air: Chamunda Mata Temple can be reached from the nearest Jodhpur Airport (6 km) which is well connected with regular domestic flights to Delhi, Mumbai.When I went to see Jodhpur Fort, I also saw this temple. place_name: Gayatri Shaktipeeth Shree Chamunda Mata Temple
review: Mehrangarh (which is the gateway to the Gayatri Shaktipeeth Shri Chamunda Mata temple) is a very beautiful and well maintained fort overlooking the whole of Jodhpur and showing a lot of the city’s history.After paying the entrance fee you’ll be let in to the fort. A ticket for foreigners is ₹600 (or ₹400 for students) and includes an audio tour, unfortunately the device doesn’t come with headphones and you’ll have to walk around holding it against your ear for a few hours.The museum is beautiful, clean and really well maintained, especially if you compare it to other museums and exhibition rooms in India. The fort it self is an architectural masterpiece, especially considering the time it was build.After visiting the fort and the museum you can make your way true the garden and visit the temple, which will give you the absolute best view on the blue city.Mehrangarh (which is the gateway to the Gayatri Shaktipeeth Shri Chamunda Mata temple) is a very beautiful and well maintained fort overlooking the whole of Jodhpur and showing a lot of the city’s history.

Pretty "little" (compared to everything the city og Jodhpur has to offer!) place with ancient architecture and a pretty rivetting history and historic significance. Don't go down the stairs, it's either banned or frowned upon. Many angles for clicking nice photos.

Really great place to spend a peaceful morning in. The famous mehrangarh fort is just a small hike away from this bavdi (step well). You’re free to take a dip in and go for a swim. There’ll be photo shoots as well so make sure to go early morning to avoid rush.

Toorji Ka Jhalra, Jodhpur Constructed in 1740, Toorji Ka Jhalra, commonly called stepwell of Jodhpur, is an intricate design of stepwell, one of the few remaining structures depicting the traditional water management systems of Jodhpur. This architectural wonder was built by the queen-consort of Maharaja Abhaya Singh, a sign of the age-old tradition of the region where royal women were in charge of overseeing the public water works. The design and structure help onlookers comprehend the lifestyle of the earlier generations who had used it in its prime, with the site serving as the local watering hole for its time.This 250-year-old structure was made using the famous rose-red sandstone found in Jodhpur. More than 200 feet in depth, it was once adorned with intricate carvings of dancing elephants, medieval lions, cow waterspouts, and niches that showed various deities. There were two levels of access and a separate tank which were meant to receive water from the wheel system powered by the bullocks. Its impressive design attracts many tourists, and is regarded as a fun place by locals and visitors to engage in harmless, recreational water games in order to beat the heat.Toorji Ka Jhalra, Jodhpur Constructed in 1740, Toorji Ka Jhalra, commonly called stepwell of Jodhpur, is an intricate design of stepwell, one of the few remaining structures depicting the traditional water management systems of Jodhpur.

The lake attracts birdwatchers as it's a habitat for various migratory birds. Kaylana Lake in Jodhpur, Rajasthan is located 8 kms to the west of Jodhpur on the Jaiselmer road. Pratap Singh, the then Prime Minister of Jodhpur, got the lake constructed in 1872. This artificial lake is spread over 84 square kms. Where the lake now lies, was once an area having palaces and gardens of two rulers of Jodhpur. They were destroyed to make the Kaylana Lake. Near to the lake is a Dak Bungalow of PHED, the Irrigation department. There are also boating facilities available for the tourists here.An ideal picnic spot for tourists, this lake offers a breathtaking view of the sunset. At that time the sky looks like a canvas splashed with spectacular colors. Kaylana Lake is the perfect place to relax or have picnics. If you are interested in birds, then, this place will further interest you. Also known by the name of Pratap Sagar, the area around this lake was once full of wild bears. It served as a secured hunting place for the royal members. But, with the increase in population it has not remained so.Don't even try to swim in this if you are not an expert swimmer. Better still, don't swim at all. Many youngsters trying to swim across this deep lake have lost their lives. Inspite of this, Kaylana Lake is a charming picnic spot. The beauty of this place will keep on lingering with you for a long time after your visit.Kaylana Lake in Jodhpur, Rajasthan is located 8 kms to the west of Jodhpur on the Jaiselmer road. Rao Jodha Desert Rock Park located near the Mehrangarh Fort contains distinctive volcanic rock and sandstone formations. Here you can witness the attempt of architectural and ecological restoration. The park was established in 2006 and public access was granted in February 2011. It houses Visitors Centre, a plant nursery and a small cafe.Since, I visited with family (having a 6 years kid) the ticket seller advised as to choose Yellow trails among the available four trails (yellow, green, red, and blue trails). The trails of around 1km long were well-marked with colored arrows and perfect for hiking and learning about the desert‘s characteristics and geology which may take around 4-5 hours to cover the entire area.The ticket seller was very facilitative who explained us all the different sections and trails providing a useful map. The Blue trail can not be accessed without guide and hence requires to contact them one day before your visit. The elephant passages were quite beautiful.It showcases incredible flora fauna biodiversity. It is a museum of plants in the rocky deserts of Marwar. A little pond was also picturesque where you can feel relaxed. I found it as the most under rated place in Jodhpur but I recommend all the travelers to add this place to your itinerary.Precautions: 1. Visit early in the morning. In summer: around 7AM and in winter: around 8-9AM.2. Wear comfortable clothes and shoes3. Carry water bottle & some snacks4. Use sunscreen cream/lotion for the non early morning trips.Guide fee: Rs. 200 for a groupEntry fee: Rs. 100 per personPlayground: No playground is hereRestrooms: No restroom is available hereRao Jodha Desert Rock Park located near the Mehrangarh Fort contains distinctive volcanic rock and sandstone formations. The most under rated place in Jodhpur. It's beautiful and has different plants which are available. The narrow passages which are called elephant passages are quite beautiful. This desert park rewilding is a breath of fresh air - literally, in the hubbub of Jodhpur. It's probably also the cleanest few square kilometres of India, and even some quiet spots where you can barely hear the humanity lurking nearby. Please go and support them!! One negative: their website says they open at 7.30am, their brochure and Google maps say 8am, but today the ticket office opened at... 8.55am. Along with the usual face-saving attempt at an excuse. Anyway, I had already entered.the park without waiting for them, and looped back to pay later. I'd suggest doing this if no-one shows up. The whole point is to get in early to avoid the heat, and when there is more birdlife in particular. One last thing to note: there are several groups of wild dogs in there, some are friendly, but others are a bit scary and bark at you. I felt unsafe alone a couple of times. I'd recommend going with someone or have a good stone in your hand. One last thing: this place should have a 5-star average, but the only reason it doesn't, is that, after reading the reviews, there seem to be a whole bunch of Indian tourists who wouldn't recognise a piece of peaceful and CLEAN nature if it bit them in the face. I feel quite sad for them. They just need to stay in their polluted, rubbish-filled cities and leave the nice parts of India to people who might appreciate them. Everyone wins!This desert park rewilding is a breath of fresh air - literally, in the hubbub of Jodhpur. It's probably also the cleanest few square kilometres of India, and even some quiet spots where you can barely hear the humanity lurking nearby.
