One of the tourist attractions is Kans Qila in Mathura which is believed to be the fort of Kansa, the Maternal Uncle of Lord Krishna. Hence, it dates back to the period of the great epic Mahabharata in 7th century BCE. Kans Qila is situated near Krishna Ganga Ghat and Gau Ghat in Mathura. This fort (qila) was built in a large area which was fenced with a long wall. Over the centuries, the fort got ruined and in the 16th century, it was renovated by Raja Man Singh of Amber who was the general of Mughal Emperor Akbar. The architecture of the fort is the blend of Hindu and Muslim architecture. Later, an observatory was built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh of Jaipur who was also a famous astrologer but it does not exist today. In olden times, Kans Qila was believed to be a saviour to protect the people of Mathura against the floods in Yamuna River as it is situated on the northern banks of the river.The old hall of audience is a stunning and notable building and was divided into three aisles. The hall is situated outside the fort and is made of red stand-stone pillars. The fort was sold to the Government contractor before the mutiny who destroyed it for the materials it contained. After the mutiny, it was converted as a school and its beauty and architecture were all ruined by the rulers then by covering them with mud wall. Today, one can only see the dilapidated fort due to its improper maintenance. It is also called as Old Fort or Purana Qila of Mathura.One of the tourist attractions is Kans Qila in Mathura which is believed to be the fort of Kansa, the Maternal Uncle of Lord Krishna. Hence, it dates back to the period of the great epic Mahabharata in 7th century BCE. Kans Qila is situated

Mind blowing placeGovardhan Hill in Hindi Govardhana Parvata; also called Mount Govardhana and Giriraj, is a sacred Hindu site in the Mathura district of Uttar Pradesh, India on an 8 km long hill located in the area of Govardhan and Radha Kund, which is about 21 kilometres approx. from Vrindavan.The name 'Govardhana' has two primary translations. In the literal meaning, 'Go' translates to 'cows', and 'vardhana' translates to 'nourishment' in the sense of  taking care of their food as well as increase their number and productivity of milk, butter & it's other products.Another meaning of 'Go' is 'the senses' and 'vardhana' can also mean 'to increase' - thus the name is also translated by devotees of Krishna as 'that which increases the senses' for their betterment of soul and mind.Moreover, It is believed that the personality of Govardhan blesses the devotee by increasing his devotion.It is the sacred centre of Braj and is identified as a natural form of Krishna, the Govardhana Shila(Rock).Mind blowing placeGovardhan Hill in Hindi Govardhana Parvata; also called Mount

As a devotee, I have had the great privilege of visiting the Arulmigu Ramanathaswamy Temple in Rameswaram couple of times. It is one of the twelve Jyotirlinga temples, and it is a truly sacred and magnificent place of worship.The temple complex is vast and sprawling, with a number of different temples and shrines. Here are a few of the most notable ones:Ramanathaswamy Temple: This is the main temple in the complex, and it houses the deity of Ramanathaswamy, which is a jyotirlinga (a lingam of light).Corridors: The temple is famous for its long corridors (maybe the World's longest corridor), which are lined with over 1,200 pillars.Kotilingeshwara Temple: This temple is home to over 10 million lingams.Gandhamadana Parvatham: This is a sacred hill that is located within the temple complex.Panchalinga Temple: This temple houses five lingams, which represent the five elements of nature (earth, water, fire, air, and space).The temple complex also has a number of other shrines, including shrines to Hanuman Ji, Lord Rama, and Srimati Sita Devi.In addition to being a place of worship, the Arulmigu Ramanathaswamy Temple is also a place where people can come to receive free food. The temple serves annadanam (food distribution) to thousands of people every day. The annadanam program was started in the 17th century, and it continues to this day.The Arulmigu Ramanathaswamy Temple is believed to have been built in the 12th century by the Pandya dynasty. The temple has been expanded and renovated over the centuries by various dynasties, including the Cholas, the Vijayanagara Empire, and the British.The temple has stood the test of time for over a thousand years. It has survived numerous invasions and natural disasters. The temple is a testament to the resilience of the faith of Sanathana Dharma and the devotion of its followers.Visited on
Weekend

Ramanathaswamy Temple (Rāmanātasvāmi Kōyil) is a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Shiva located on Rameswaram island in the state of Tamil Nadu, India. It is also one of the twelve Jyotirlinga temples. It is one of the 275 Paadal Petra Sthalams, where three of the most revered Nayanars (Saivite saints), Appar, Sundarar and Tirugnana Sambandar, have glorified the temple with their songs. The temple was expanded during the 12th century by the Pandya Dynasty, and its principal shrine’s sanctum was renovated by Jeyaveera Cinkaiariyan and his successor Gunaveera Cinkaiariyan, monarchs of the Jaffna kingdom. The temple has the longest corridor among all Hindu temples in India. It was built by King Muthuramalinga Sethupathiy. [1] [2] The temple, located in Rameswaram, is considered a holy pilgrimage site for Shaivites, Vaishnavites and Smarthas. Mythological accounts depict the presiding deity, the Lingam of Ramanathaswamy (Shiva), as having been established and worshiped by Rama, before he crossed his bridge to the present-day island of Sri Lanka. It is one of the Char Dham pilgrimage sites.Visited on

So, I went to this place, and trust me, leave your phone behind. It's best to absorb the experience of reading and observing his statues.Let me share what I witnessed. His bag contained two simple notebooks where he recorded his thoughts and daily routine. It taught me the essence of humility. Despite being such an extraordinary person, he kept things so simple. It empowers me to embrace humility and simplicity. I noticed his slippers and shoes neatly arranged — a profound symbol of humility that's hard to put into words. Everything displayed in the museum about him encourages a more efficient life with fewer possessions. Lord Krishna's words echo through, emphasizing doing everything as "seva" for others.APJ Abdul Kalam Sir will forever be my inspiration to remain humble, down-to-earth, always ready to give, and dedicated to making a positive impact. He motivates me to simplify my life, avoid unnecessary displays, and consistently contribute to others' well-being. The APJ Abdul Kalam Memorial in Rameshwaram is a truly remarkable place that pays tribute to the renowned scientist and former President of India, Dr. APJ Abdul Kalam. Visiting this memorial was an enriching experience.This memorial serves as a fitting tribute to the man affectionately known as the "Missile Man of India." The meticulous preservation of Dr. Kalam's memory is evident throughout the site. One of the most poignant aspects is the remembrance of his final moments during his lecture in Shillong. This somber yet respectful acknowledgment of his last moments adds depth to the memorial.Inside the memorial, you'll find a collection of Dr. Kalam's personal belongings, including his notebook, laptop, and a few items of clothing. These artifacts provide an intimate insight into the life and personality of this remarkable individual.The APJ Abdul Kalam Memorial is a place that not only educates but also inspires. It's a testament to the legacy of a visionary scientist and leader whose contributions to India and the world continue to be celebrated. A visit to this memorial is a journey through history and an opportunity to pay homage to one of India's greatest sons.The only regret is that photography is not allowed inside the building so cannot share photos.The APJ Abdul Kalam Memorial in Rameshwaram is a truly remarkable place that pays tribute to the renowned scientist and former President of India, Dr. APJ Abdul Kalam. Visiting this memorial was an enriching experience.

One of the popular theertham in Rameshwaram, Agnitheertham is also associated with Lord Rama and Goddess Sita. According to the legend, after the Lanka war, lord Rama before praying to Lord Shiva as a penance had taken bath in this theertham. There is one more legend, according to which, it is here when Goddess Sita had entered the fire, when doubts were raised on her chastity as she had stayed in demon Ravana confinement. She was unhurt and Lord Angi appeared to prove the pureness of Goddess Sita. However, as he had touched Goddess, he prayed Lord Shiva to atone his sins. It is then he had taken bath here. Hence, it is believed that taking a dip in the holy waters of Agnitheertham relive devotees of their past sins.One of the popular theertham in Rameshwaram, Agnitheertham is also associated with Lord Rama and Goddess Sita. place_name: House of Kalam (APJ Abdul Kalam House
review: Dr. Abdul Kalam's House is conveniently situated near the renowned Rameswaram temple. Once a humble seaside abode, it has now been reconstructed into a splendid two-story building. The ground floor is occupied by Kalam's relatives, adding a personal touch to the visit. Prepare to be amazed as you step into the very place where the great Kalam sir was born. This extraordinary location fills us with immense pride for our nation and its exceptional leaders.Inside the house, you'll find two floors to explore. The first floor is a treasure trove of memorabilia, showcasing all the honors and milestones that Dr. Kalam achieved throughout his illustrious life. On the top floor, there's a delightful souvenir shop and a book store, perfect for picking up a memento or two.While you'll undoubtedly want to capture the memories, please note that photography is not permitted inside the house. To reach this remarkable destination, you'll need to navigate through a narrow lane off the main road, approximately one kilometer away from the Ramanathaswamy temple.Dr. Abdul Kalam's House is conveniently situated near the renowned Rameswaram temple. Ramanathaswamy Temple is a Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva located on Rameswaram island, Tamil Nadu. It is also one of the 12 Jyotirlinga temples in India. The temple has the longest corridor among all Hindu temples in India.Per Mythology, the presiding deity, the Lingam of Ramanathaswamy (Shiva), was established and worshiped by Lord Rama, before He crossed the bridge to the present-day island of Sri Lanka. The temple in its current form is believed to have been built during the 17th century.There are sixty-four Tirthas (holy water bodies) in and around the island of Rameswaram. Bathing in these Tirthas is a major aspect of the pilgrimage to Rameswaram. Twenty-two of the Tīrthas are within the Ramanathaswamy Temple. These 22 theerthams represent the 22 arrows in Lord Rama's quiver.It is believed that pilgrims follow the below sequence when visiting Ramanathaswamy Temple in Rameswaram:1. Take bath in the sea, which is about 500 meters away from the temple2. Enter the temple from North gate for 22 theertham bathing; once done exit from South Gate (Ticket price - Rs. 25)3. Enter the temple from East gate for deity darshan (Ticket prices: Free - Regular darshan, Rs. 100 - Special darshan and Rs. 200 - Quick darshan)Note - Mobile phones are not permitted inside the temple premises; Use locker facility to keep phones and belongings.Ramanathaswamy Temple is located about 2.5 kms away from Rameshwaram Bus Stand. One can use bus, cab or autorickshaw facilities to commute.Visited on
Weekend

Wait time

Vaishno Devi (also known as Mata Rani, Trikuta, Ambe and Vaishnavi) is a manifestation of the Hindu mother goddess Durga or Adi Shakti.Vaishno Devi is worshipped as a combined avatar of the goddesses Mahakali, Mahalakshmi, and Mahasaraswati. And She is the Kaliyugi Avatar of Kalika. Additionally, she is seen as the potency of Hari or Vishnu.History of Vaishno MataThe temple of Mata Vaishno Devi is very ancient according to the study conducted by the geologists. Legend has it that Mata Vaishno Devi had incarnated as a beautiful princess in Treta Yuga as a Shakti of Mother Parvati, Saraswati and Lakshmi for the welfare of mankind. She performed penances in the cave on Trikuta Mountain. When the time came, her body merged into the astral form of the three divine energies – Mahakali, Mahalakshmi and Mahasaraswati.Her ardent devotee – ShridharOf all the popular legends of Mata Vaishno Devi, the most recent one is that of her ardent devotee, Shridhar, who lived about seven centuries ago. Shridhar and his wife were very devoted to the Mother Goddess. Once, Shridhar received a divine command in his dream to organise a bhandhara (public feast) in Her honour. Owing to his humble financial status, Shridhar failed to procure sufficient groceries for the public feast. He worried about the shame and guilt he shall be subject for failing to feed the guests the following day. Unable to sleep a wink the whole night, Shridhar resigned himself to destiny. As the sun rose in the firmament, villagers began arriving at the modest dwelling of Shridhar to partake of the feast. To Shridhar’s surprise, Goddess Vaishnavi appeared in his hut in the form of a little girl and by Her Will, the feast was prepared and served to the villagers. The villagers had their fill of the food except Bhairon Nath, who was one of the guests. When he demanded a meal of animal meal from Shridhar, Vaishno Mata refused to oblige Bhairon Nath on Shridhar’s behalf. Refusing to accept defeat and insult, Bhairon tried to catch hold of the divine girl, but failed to do so. Lo and behold! The girl vanished. This incident left other shocked, and Shridhar grief-stricken. He longed and pined to have darshan of His Mother. One night, Vaishno Mata appeared in Shridhar’s dream and showed him a way to a cave on Trikuta Mountain which houses her ancient shrine. Shridhar gladly did as told, discovered the holy shrine and devoted his life to her service. Later, the word spread everywhere about the shrine of Mata Vaishno Devi.Vaishno MataAccording to the holy writ, before the great war between the Kurus and the Pandavas was about to begin in Kurukshetra, Lord Krishna advised Arjuna to worship Goddess Durga to obtains her grace. During his prayers, Arjun Arjun addresses the Divine Mother as ‘Jambookatak Chityaishu Nityam Sannihitalaye’, which translates into ‘you who always dwell in the temple on the slope of the mountain in Jamboo’ (‘Jamboo’ comes from Jamboodweep, also refers to, India and its surrounding lands in ancient times). Pleased with his devotion, the Divine Mother grants Arjun the boon of victory over his enemies. It is also believed that the Pandavas have visited the shrine of Vaishno Devi on Trikuta mountain.The divine call…It is a belief held in sacred regard by the devotees of Divine Mother that unless She beckons you to visit her, it is impossible to have her darshan. The bulawa (or Divine Call) to receive blessings of the Mother is all that is needed and the rest will be taken care of by Her. Therefore, high or low, wise or ignorant, men or women await Her bulawa.The way to the shrine…Pilgrims and ardent devotees of the Mother Goddess brave the arduous 24 kilometre long trek (to and fro) to reach the shrine that is always brimming with overwhelming divine vibrations. The journey to the shrine starts at Ban Ganga in Katra which is believed to have sprung up from the earth when Vaishno Mata shot up an arrow from her divine bow many centuries ago. Maa Vaishno Devi is believed to grant four boons to her devotees namely Dharma (Righteousness), Artha (Material Pursuits), Kaama (Contentment), and Moksha (Enlightenment).The Maa Vaishno Devi Dham, located in the holy city of Vrindavan, was founded by Sh. J C Chaudhry. Spread across 12 acres of land, the Dham provides an opportunity to all the devotees of Maa Vaishno Devi to worship their goddess and serve the poor alongside. Every year lakhs of devotees visit the Dham from all parts of India and abroad.Sh. J C Chaudhry is the Managing Trustee and the founder of Maa Vaishno Devi Dham at Vrindavan. With a staunch belief in Maa Vaishno Devi, whom he always considers as a source of support and inspiration, Sh. J C Chaudhry established the Dham to reciprocate to the Goddess for all her love, care, and blessings.In 2013, Limca Book of Records recognized the magnificent Maa Vaishno Devi Murti as the tallest statue (141 feet in height) in India.His idea of a dedicated Dham for devotees, however, could not have been completed without the magnificent Maa Vaishno Murti, (standing at an impressive height of 141ft from ground level), Devi Mandir, Darshan Gufa, Bhojanalaya, Free Dispensary, Atithi Niwas, Spiritual Hall, Meditation Hall, Yoga Hall, and Library etc.In his quest to reciprocate to the Goddess for all her love, care, and blessings, Sh. Chaudhry built the Maa Vaishno Dham. The location of Dham is holy as Vrindavan is the place where Lord Krishna observed his childhood.This grand contribution by Sh. Chaudhry is his endeavour to relinquish it back to society through his religious involvements. Sh. Chaudhry is a philanthropist who has always believed in making a difference through his noble pursuits. He has set a number of precedents through his community building ventures and Maa Vaishno Devi Dham is one of them.Maa Vaishno Devi is believed to grant four boons to her devotees namely Dharma (Righteousness), Artha (Material Pursuits), Kaama (Contentment), and Moksha (Enlightenment).

🚩🚩🚩JAI MATA DI 🚩🚩🚩Recently visited Maa Vaishno Devi Dham—an enchanting destination that's a must-see in Vrindavan. The spiritual aura and captivating surroundings left me in awe. A truly divine experience that touched my soul.

Nestled in the heart of Vrindavan, Maa Vaishno Devi Dham stands as a beacon of spiritual enlightenment and devotion. This sacred temple complex is a divine abode that has captivated the hearts of countless pilgrims and devotees from all corners of the world. In this review, I will attempt to paint a vivid picture of my transformative experience at Maa Vaishno Devi Dham, which encompasses not just a temple but an entire spiritual sanctuary.The first thing that strikes you upon arriving at Maa Vaishno Devi Dham is its serene and tranquil ambiance. Surrounded by lush green gardens, the temple complex offers a respite from the hustle and bustle of everyday life. The meticulously maintained gardens and pathways exude a sense of peace and harmony, setting the tone for the spiritual journey that lies ahead.The main temple, dedicated to Maa Vaishno Devi, is a true architectural marvel. Its intricate design, adorned with vibrant colors and ornate carvings, is a testament to the craftsmanship of the artisans who built it. As you approach the temple, you can't help but feel a sense of awe and reverence. The sheer grandeur of the temple is overwhelming, and it immediately transports you to a higher state of consciousness.Inside the temple, the atmosphere is electric with devotion. The melodious chants of hymns and the fragrance of incense fill the air, creating a sacred aura that envelops you. The idol of Maa Vaishno Devi, adorned in resplendent attire, radiates divinity and grace. It's impossible not to be moved by the profound sense of spirituality that permeates every corner of this sacred space.One of the most remarkable aspects of Maa Vaishno Devi Dham is its commitment to inclusivity and diversity. Devotees from all walks of life, irrespective of their caste, creed, or nationality, are welcomed with open arms. This universal acceptance and unity in diversity are a true reflection of the teachings of Maa Vaishno Devi herself.The temple complex also offers various amenities for pilgrims. The prasad (holy offering) distributed at the temple is not just a source of nourishment for the body but also a symbol of divine blessings. The cleanliness and hygiene standards maintained in the dining area are commendable, ensuring a comfortable and fulfilling experience for all visitors.One of the highlights of my visit was the opportunity to participate in the evening aarti (prayer ceremony). The aarti is a mesmerizing spectacle, with the temple illuminated by countless lamps and the sounds of devotional songs filling the air. It's a moment of pure transcendence, where one feels connected to the divine on a profound level.Beyond the temple, Maa Vaishno Devi Dham offers a range of educational and cultural activities. The spiritual discourses and lectures provide valuable insights into the teachings of Maa Vaishno Devi and the broader philosophy of Hinduism. The temple also hosts cultural events and festivals, allowing visitors to immerse themselves in the rich tapestry of Indian traditions and customs.In conclusion, Maa Vaishno Devi Dham Vrindavan is not just a temple; it's a spiritual sanctuary where one can experience a deep connection with the divine. Its serene ambiance, awe-inspiring architecture, and inclusive ethos make it a must-visit destination for anyone on a spiritual quest. My visit to this sacred place was a transformative journey that left an indelible mark on my soul. I can only express my gratitude for the opportunity to experience the divinity of Maa Vaishno Devi Dham and the profound sense of peace and enlightenment it offers to all who seek it.Wait time

review: Very near to Shri Banke Bihari Hi temple & Parikrama Marg.This temple is around 5000 years old and is one of the oldest temple in Vrindavan.This temple was invaded by Mughals and tried to completely demolish the temple,But The main Deity(Madan Mohan ji) was secretly taken to a safe place.

review: Shri Radha Madan Mohan Ji ki Jai !!!🙏🏻🙏🏻It is one of the Oldest temples of Braj Bhoomi. Very calm and peaceful place. But it lacks cleanliness and maintenance.There was a stray dog who openly peed at the entrance of this temple (can be seen in my video) Further, there was no clear sign indicating where the footwear need to be removed. Also, there are so many monkeys around that you can leave your footwear unattended.So if you are coming here for the first time, you can remove your footwear at the chappal stand near the main gate.The place is so peaceful in the morning and also it is very sacred as a great saint Sanatan Goswamiji used to do Kirtan here.Do visit this place whenever you come to Vrindavan! Sevakunj in Vrindavan appears to be a place of historical significance, but sadly, it has not received the care it deserves. The site is quite old and appears neglected, with a lack of maintenance, cleanliness, and hygiene in the surroundings.It's disheartening to see the decline of what must have once been a holy place. It's unfortunate that both the government and the local community have not taken better care of it, allowing it to deteriorate. It's puzzling why people continue to visit and potentially contribute to further pollution in the area.Within Sevakunj, you can find small temples and Nidhivan, and the Yamuna River is nearby. If you do plan to visit, I recommend going in the morning around 9 or in the evening at 4:30. Auto rickshaws are not very common in this area, so transportation might be a challenge. Also, be cautious of the mischievous monkeys that are often found there.Sevakunj in Vrindavan appears to be a place of historical significance, but sadly, it has not received the care it deserves. A Beautiful place and here we can feed monkeys and they won't cause any trouble to us.This is the place where Shri Krishna used to do Padaseva ,So there is an idol in the Temple inside it where Shri Krishna is holding Mata Radha's feet in his hands.

Seva Kunj, also known as Nikunj Van, is located in Vrindavan.The place is known as Seva Kunj because ShriKrishna does seva (selfless service) of RadhaRani here daily.It has a beautiful temple dedicated to Radha Krishna which is also known as Rang Mahal. The temple’s walls are decorated with paintings of various leelas performed here by RadhaKrishna. Each painting depicts different aspect of Radha and Krishna. One of the painting depicts Krishna combing and decorating hairs of Radha. In another painting, Lord Krishna is massaging legs of Radha after she is tired of Raas Leela. Other paintings depicts RadhaKrishna playing Holi and in one Krishna is enthralling Radha while playing flute.RadheRadhe 💜HareKrishna   Seva Kunj, also known as Nikunj Van, is located in Vrindavan.The place is known as Seva Kunj because ShriKrishna does seva (selfless service) of RadhaRani here daily.

"सेवा कुंज या निकुंज वन "रासलीला के श्रम से व्यथित राधा जी की भगवान् द्वारा यह सेवा किए जाने के कारण इस स्थान का नाम सेवाकुंज पडा. सेवाकुंज वृंदावन के प्राचीन दर्शनीय स्थलों में से एक है. राधादामोदर जी मन्दिर के निकट ही कुछ पूर्व-दक्षिण कोण में यह स्थान स्थित है.स्थापना - गोस्वामी श्री हित हरिवंश जी ने सन 1590 में अन्य अनेक लीला स्थलों के साथ इसे भी प्रकट किया था.शेष री विग्रह - यहाँ एक छोटे-से मन्दिर में राधा जी के चित्रपट की पूजा होती है. लता दु्रमों से आच्छादित सेवाकुंज के मध्य में एक भव्य मंदिर है, जिसमें श्री कृष्ण राधा जी के चरण दबाते हुए अति सुंदर रूप में विराजमान है. राधा जी की ललितादि सखियों के भी चित्रपट मंदिर की शोभा बढा रहे हैं.साथ में ललिता विशाखा जी भी दर्शन है.सेवा कुंज में ललिता-कुण्ड है. जहाँ रास के समय ललिता जी को प्यास लगने पर कृष्ण ने अपनी वेणु(वंशी) से खोदकर एक सुन्दर कुण्ड को प्रकट किया. जिसके सुशीतल मीठे जल से सखियों के साथ ललिता जी ने जलपान किया था.सेवाकुंज के बीचोंबीच एक पक्का चबूतरा है, जनश्रुति है कि यहाँ आज भी नित्य रात्रि को रासलीला होती है.सेवाकुंज का इतिहास :वृंदावन श्यामा जू और श्री कुंज विहारी का निज धाम है. यहां राधा-कृष्ण की प्रेमरस-धारा बहती रहती है. मान्यता है कि चिरयुवाप्रिय-प्रियतम श्री धाम वृंदावन में सदैव विहार में संलग्न रहते हैं.भक्त रसखान ब्रज में सर्वत्र कृष्ण को खोज खोज कर हार गये, अन्त में यहीं पर रसिक कृष्ण का उन्हें दर्शन हुआ। उन्होंने अपने पद में उस झाँकी का वर्णन इस प्रकार किया है -देख्यो दुर्यों वह कुंज कुटीर में।बैठ्यो पलोटत राधिका पायन ॥मन्दिर में एक शय्या शयन के लिए है, जिसके विषय में कहा जाता है की रात्रि में प्रिया प्रितम साक्षात् रूप में आज भी इस पर विश्राम करते हैं । साथ ही सेवाकुंज के बीचों बीच एक पक्का चबूतरा है, ब्रजवासियों का कहना है कि आज भी प्रत्येक रात्रि में श्री राधा कृष्ण-युगल साक्षात् रूप से यहाँ विहार करते हैं.इस विहार लीला को कोई नहीं देख सकता, दिन भर में हजारों बंदर, पक्षी, जीव जंतु सेवाकुंज में रहते है पर जैसे ही शाम होती है,सब जीव जंतु बंदर अपने आप सेवाकुंज से चले जाते है एक परिंदा भी फिर वहाँ पर नहीं रुकता.यहाँ तक कि जमीन के अंदर के जीव चीटी आदि भी जमीन के अंदर चले जाते है रास लीला को कोई नहीं देख सकता क्योकि रास लीला इस लौकिक जगत की लीला नहीं है रास तो अलौकिक जगत की "परम दिव्याति दिव्य लीला" है कोई साधारण व्यक्ति या जीव अपनी आँखों से देख ही नहीं सकता. जो बड़े बड़े संत है उन्हें सेवाकुंज से राधारानी जी और गोपियों के नुपुर की ध्वनि सुनी है.जब रास करते करते राधा रानी जी थक जाती है तो बिहारी जी उनके चरण दबाते है. और रात्रि में शयन करते है आज भी यहाँ शय्या शयन कक्ष है जहाँ पुजारी जी जल का पात्र, पान, दातुन, लड्डू, फुल और प्रसाद रखते है, और जब सुबह पट खोलते है तो जल पीला मिलता है पान चबाया हुआ मिलता है, दातुन करी हुई मिलती है और फूल की सेज दबी हुई और सारे फूल बिखरे हुए मिलते है.बोलो सेवा कुंज धाम की जय हो ||"सेवा कुंज या निकुंज वन "रासलीला के श्रम से व्यथित राधा जी की भगवान् द्वारा यह सेवा किए जाने के कारण इस

"Seva Kunj or Nikunj Forest"Due to this service done by God to Radha ji who was distressed due to the labor of Raasleela, this place was named Seva Kunj. Sevakunj is one of the ancient tourist places of Vrindavan. This place is situated in some east-south corner near Radhadamodar ji temple.Establishment - Goswami Shri Hit Harivansh ji had revealed this along with many other Leela places in the year 1590.Shesh Ri Vigraha - Here the picture of Radha ji is worshiped in a small temple. There is a grand temple in the middle of Seva Kunj covered with creeper leaves, in which Shri Krishna is seated in a very beautiful form, pressing the feet of Radha ji. Pictures of Radha ji's friends Lalita and others are also enhancing the beauty of the temple. Along with this, Lalita Vishakha ji is also visible.There is Lalita-Kund in Seva Kunj. Where during Raas, when Lalita ji felt thirsty, Krishna dug a beautiful pond with his Venu (vanshi). Lalita ji had taken refreshment from its cool sweet water along with her friends. There is a concrete platform in the middle of Seva Kunj, it is a rumor that even today Rasleela is performed here every night.History of Seva Kunj:Vrindavan is the personal abode of Shyama Ju and Shri Kunj Vihari. Here the stream of love of Radha-Krishna keeps flowing. It is believed that the eternally beloved always remains engaged in pilgrimage in Shri Dham Vrindavan.Devotee Raskhan searched for Krishna everywhere in Braj and got lost, finally it was here only here that he saw Rasik Krishna. He has described that tableau in his post as follows -Look, Durya, that grove in the cottage.Sityo palotat Radhika Payan.There is a bed in the temple for sleeping, about which it is said that even today Priya Pritam rests on it in physical form at night. Also, there is a concrete platform in the middle of Seva Kunj, the people of Braj say that even today Shri Radha Krishna-couple walk here in person every night.No one can see this Vihar Leela, thousands of monkeys, birds and animals stay in Seva Kunj throughout the day, but as soon as evening comes, all the animals and monkeys automatically leave Seva Kunj and not even a bird stays there again.Even the underground creatures like ants etc. go underground. No one can see Raas Leela because Raas Leela is not the Leela of this worldly world. Raas is the "Supreme Divine Divine Leela" of the supernatural world. No ordinary person or The living being cannot see with its eyes. The great saints have heard the sound of Radharani ji and the chanting of Gopis from Seva Kunj.When Radha Rani ji gets tired while performing the Raas, Bihari ji presses her feet. And they sleep at night, even today there is a bed in the bedroom where the priest keeps a vessel of water, paan, datun, laddu, flower and prasad, and when the door is opened in the morning, the water is yellow, paan is chewed, datun is found. It is found cooked and the flower bed is found buried and all the flowers are scattered.Say Jai Seva Kunj Dham."Seva Kunj or Nikunj Forest"

The Dwarkadhish Temple, touted as one of the holiest temples in Mathura, is famous all over the country for its elaborate architecture and paintings. Built in 1814, the temple is relatively new but is highly revered. The temple is dedicated to Lord Dwarkadheesh, a form of Lord Krishna known as Dwarkanath, depicted in a black marble idol.An array of beautiful ceiling paintings showcasing the various aspects of the Lord's life and the beautiful Rajasthani architectural designs and carving makes the complex look even more magnanimous. The Dwarkadhish temple is currently managed by the followers of Vaishnava sect (started by Mahaprabhu Vallabhacharya) and is a centre for lots of interesting activities all year round especially during the Shravan months when the Lord's Idol is placed inside a Hindola a (type of a swing set). Other important festivals celebrated are Holi, Diwali and Janmashtami.Situated within the perimeter of the city's holy gate, near the ghats of River Yamuna, the temple and its surroundings are a hub of a lot of interesting activities. Thousands of devotees arrive here every day to pay their obeisance.जय श्री कृष्णा 🙏🙏Wait time
No wait

Reservation recommended

I recently had the privilege of visiting Marudhamalai Arulmigu Subramanya Swami Temple  in Coimbatore with my family, and I must say it was an experience of a lifetime. From the moment we arrived on a sunny morning, the temple greeted us with its serene ambiance and breathtaking beauty.To begin with, reaching the temple was a breeze as there was a convenient bus service available that took us all the way to the top. This thoughtful provision made the journey hassle-free for our group of 12 family members, allowing us to fully immerse ourselves in the spiritual adventure that awaited us.Upon reaching the top, we were captivated by the awe-inspiring panoramic view that unfolded before our eyes. The picturesque scenery surrounding the temple, with lush greenery and majestic hills, created a sense of tranquility that instantly put us at ease.The priests at the temple deserve special mention for their warm and welcoming nature. They guided us through the rituals and provided insightful information about the temple's history and significance. Their genuine devotion and dedication added to the sacred atmosphere of the place, making our visit even more meaningful.One aspect that stood out during our visit was the temple's impeccable cleanliness. The entire premises were well-maintained, reflecting the devotion and respect for the divine space. It was truly a pleasure to explore the temple's various sections, all of which exuded a sense of serenity and purity.As we embarked on this spiritual journey, we were filled with a profound sense of peace and positivity. The Temple provided us with an opportunity to connect with the divine in a meaningful way, leaving a lasting impression on our hearts and minds.In conclusion, I wholeheartedly recommend visiting the Marudhamalai Arulmigu Subramanya Swami Temple to anyone seeking a spiritual retreat in Coimbatore. Its scenic beauty, welcoming priests, and pristine environment make it a truly transformative experience. Whether you are a devotee or simply looking for a place to find solace, this temple offers a sacred haven that will leave you feeling refreshed and inspired.Wait time

We were there on a weekend for a function at Sadivayal, a few kms away from the falls, we made it here, as it was close by. Lucky coincidence.The whole walk, and ride from the check post/ticket counter, to the falls proper was a thrill, wonderful scenes, through timber trees, continuous sounds of insects, and distant water falls and flow.The look from the view tower on the way, was bright and clear of the foothills, to distant mountain range, with its tree cover.The falls was visible from a distance with the sounds of it's torrential flow down. We crossed the stream on the bridge and walked down the meandering steps to the bathing ghats.It was safe, with built up sides, and barricades and space for changing garments. The natural fall was masoned to help the bathers have an organised bath.Safe, secure and wonderful for a family trek, or for students, with ritualistic checking for arms and whatever, at the check points.P. S.The only place I know where everyone gets to ride the public transport, inspite of their status.Visited on

The Bada Imambara in Lucknow is an architectural marvel, known for its grandeur and historical significance. Built in the 18th century by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula, it's a symbol of Mughal architecture with its massive central hall, intricate designs, and the famous Bhulbhulaiya maze. Visitors can explore its rich history and enjoy panoramic views from the central hall's raised platform. It's a must-visit attraction showcasing the opulence of Lucknow's heritage.Visited on

Lucknow Rumi Gate is a beautiful historical monument in Lucknow, India. It's a big entrance gate that's very old and looks very fancy. People often visit it to see its amazing architecture and learn about its history.

The Rumi Darwaza is an iconic architectural masterpiece located in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, India. It is also known as the Turkish Gate or the Gateway to Lucknow. Built in 1784 during the reign of Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula, it is an example of the Awadhi architectural style and is one of the most famous landmarks in the city.The Rumi Darwaza stands at a height of about 60 feet and features intricate ornamentation and beautiful architectural details. It is constructed in the form of a large gateway with a central arched opening and two smaller arched openings on either side. The facade is adorned with stunning floral motifs, calligraphy, and Islamic inscriptions, showcasing the artistic brilliance of the craftsmen of that era.As for the reviews, the Rumi Darwaza is generally regarded as a must-visit attraction in Lucknow. Visitors appreciate the grandeur and historical significance of the gate. Many praise its impressive architecture, intricate detailing, and the overall visual appeal it adds to the cityscape of Lucknow. However, to get the most up-to-date and accurate reviews, I recommend checking travel websites, forums, or social media platforms where recent visitors share their experiences.The Rumi Darwaza is an iconic architectural masterpiece located in Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, India. Rumi Darwaza is a historical gate located in the city of Lucknow, India. It was built in the 18th century by Nawab Asaf-ud-daula and was modeled after the Sublime Porte or the gateway to Istanbul in Turkey.The gate is made of brick and lime mortar and has a height of 60 feet. It is adorned with intricate carvings and has a large central archway that is 50 feet high. There are two smaller archways on either side of the main archway.Rumi Darwaza is considered to be a fine example of Awadhi architecture and is one of the landmarks of Lucknow. It has been featured in many films and documentaries and is a popular tourist attraction.Rumi Darwaza is a historical gate located in the city of Lucknow, India. It was built in the 18th century by Nawab Asaf-ud-daula and was modeled after the Sublime Porte or the gateway to Istanbul in Turkey.

Ambedkar Memorial ParkA huge 107 acre public park in Gomti Nagar, Lucknow. This park is home to attractions like the Ambedkar Stupa, Ambedkar Samajik Parivartan Sangrahalay, Pratibimb Sthal, gallery etc. The park has around 124 big elephant statues, but the significance of it is not mentioned. The entry fee to the park is 15rs. Even with such a vast scale, it's a very well maintained and clean park. Inside the Ambedkar Sthupa, you'll find one of the most prominent structures in the premises - a magnificent bronze statue of Ambedkar, seated in a chair, at the base of this statue, you'll discover an engraved message "My struggle of life is my only message". Along with this, there are various other statues inside the sthupa that capture various significant moments from his life, showcasing his remarkable journey. When it comes to construction, mainly red sandstone is used. Whether it's day or night, this place shines with its well-placed lights that enhance its beauty. If you're planning to explore the entire area, be prepared for a stroll that will take approximately 2 hours. However, there are no food or drink options available within the premises.Ambedkar Memorial ParkA huge 107 acre public park in Gomti Nagar, Lucknow. This park is home to attractions like the Ambedkar Stupa, Ambedkar Samajik Parivartan Sangrahalay,

The Riverfront in Lucknow is a captivating and enchanting destination that seamlessly blends the historical charm of the city with modern recreational spaces. Situated along the serene banks of the Gomti River, this sprawling project has become a cultural and leisure hub, attracting locals and tourists alike. With its carefully curated design, diverse amenities, and picturesque views, the Riverfront has emerged as a testament to the city's commitment to urban development and rejuvenation.One of the most striking features of the Riverfront is its meticulous planning. The area offers a seamless integration of green spaces, recreational zones, and cultural attractions. As you walk along the promenade, you are greeted with a sense of tranquility as the river meanders gently beside you. Lush gardens, meticulously landscaped with vibrant flowers and towering trees, create a refreshing atmosphere that invites visitors to unwind and escape the hustle and bustle of the city.The architecture of the Riverfront pays homage to Lucknow's rich historical heritage. The blend of contemporary design with elements inspired by the city's Nawabi era is a visual treat. The elegant arches, ornate lamp posts, and artistic installations reflect the city's cultural grandeur. The incorporation of traditional motifs and designs seamlessly transports visitors to a bygone era, while the modern infrastructure ensures convenience and accessibility.Walking paths wind their way through the Riverfront, allowing visitors to explore the area at their own pace. The pedestrian-friendly layout encourages leisurely strolls, jogging, and cycling. For those seeking more adventurous activities, there are options for boating and kayaking on the river, providing a unique perspective of the city's skyline. The river itself is not only aesthetically pleasing, but it also holds historical significance, as it has witnessed the evolution of Lucknow over the centuries.Cultural events and festivals are an integral part of the Riverfront experience. The space serves as a venue for concerts, art exhibitions, and cultural showcases. The amphitheater, strategically positioned to maximize the river view, becomes a stage for performances that bring the community together. This convergence of arts and nature creates an atmosphere of celebration and unity.Families and children are also catered to at the Riverfront. Play areas equipped with swings, slides, and interactive installations ensure that younger visitors have their share of fun. Picnic spots allow families to spend quality time together in a serene environment, making it an ideal weekend destination for residents.The Riverfront is also a culinary haven, offering a range of dining options. From street food stalls serving local delicacies to upscale restaurants offering international cuisine, there is something to satisfy every palate. Enjoying a meal with the river as a backdrop is an experience that tantalizes both the taste buds and the senses.In conclusion, the Riverfront in Lucknow is a testament to the city's commitment to preserving its heritage while embracing modernity. The careful planning, thoughtful design, and integration of cultural, recreational, and leisure spaces make it a destination that has something to offer to everyone. Whether you're a history enthusiast, a nature lover, or someone seeking relaxation, the Riverfront is an oasis that captivates the heart and soul. It stands as a shining example of how urban spaces can be transformed into vibrant, inclusive, and sustainable havens that enrich the lives of those who visit.The Riverfront in Lucknow is a captivating and enchanting destination that seamlessly blends the historical charm of the city with modern recreational spaces. Situated along the serene banks of the Gomti River, this sprawling project has

Chattar Manzil Or Umbrella Palace is a building which served as a palace for Nawabs and their wives of Lucknow. Chattar Manzil situated on the banks of Rover Gomti near Qaiserbagh and Hazratganj. Its Mughal architecture design is very eye pleasing even nowadays when it becomes a ruined structure.It was constructed by order of Nawab Ghaziuddin Haider and completed after his death by his successor, Nawab Nadiruddin Haider. The Chattar Manzil consisted of a Bari (larger) Chattar Manzil and Chhoti (smaller) Chattar Manzil, however only the larger one still exists. The Palace has gone through many owners including the Nawabs of Awadh Saadat Ali Khan and Wajid Ali Shah, and the Britishers and changes since its construction was started in the 1780s.It's not a very great sight to go to but if you have enough time in lucknow you can visit.Chattar Manzil Or Umbrella Palace is a building which served as a palace for Nawabs and their wives of Lucknow. One of the most awe inspiring and majestic monument of Lucknow, which houses twin monuments - Farhat Baksh and Chattar Manzil. A part of ASI's list of protected monument, it was delisted in 1960s resulting in its ruin and plunder. The CDRI which was housed in this monument played havoc with its architecture and spoilt the interiors. Declared a protected monument again in 2013 by the State Archaeology, this monument is now under repairs and renovation. Chattar Manzil, the former resident palace of the Nawabs. The Chattar Manzil or Umbrella Palace is a building in Lucknow in Uttar Pradesh which served as a palace for the rulers of Awadh and their wives.It was constructed by order of Nawab Ghazi Uddin Haider and completed after his death by his successor, Nawab Nasir Uddin Haider.The Chattar Manzil stand on the banks of the River Gomti. The Chattar Manzil consisted of a Bari (larger) Chattar Manzil and Chhoti (smaller) Chattar Manzil, however only the larger one still exists. These two buildings were examples of the Indo-European-Nawabi architectural style, even though the Bari Chattar Manzil has been altered over the years. The palaces were named after the chattris (umbrella-shaped domes) on the octagonal pavilions, which crown the buildings. The imposing building has large underground rooms and a dome surmounted by a gilt umbrella.The Palace has gone through many owners including the Nawabs of Awadh Saadat Ali Khan and Wajid Ali Shah, and the British and changes since its construction was started in the 1780s.It served as a palace for the rulers of Awadh and their wives. Later during the Indian Rebellion of 1857 the building became a stronghold of the Indian revolutionaries.A portion of it was destroyed by British during the war of 1857. After the war of 1857 the government had allotted the building to an American NGO which used it as a club for recreation purposes, till 1947, the Chhatar Manzil was used as the United Services Club.Post Independence, this building was allotted to the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research which used it as Central Drug Research Institute since 1950, but now it has been vacated by CDRI.Government of Uttar Pradesh plans to set up two museums and a library at the Palace after its renovation and conservation by the State Archaeological Department.The Chattar Manzil or Umbrella Palace is a building in Lucknow in Uttar Pradesh which served as a palace for the rulers of Awadh and their wives.It was constructed by order of Nawab Ghazi Uddin Haider and completed after his

This monument has a great history in Awadh culture. Currently this building is under conservation ASI. More over you may see only two floors above the ground level but the fact is it has 2 more floors beneath. You may explore these two basement from behind the building.

Chhatar Manzil LucknowA stunning architectural marvel in Lucknow that dates back to the time of Nawabs of Lucknow, Chhatar Manzil is one of the most popular historical sites in Lucknow. The literal meaning of the term ‘Chhatar’ is Umbrella which comes from its guilt dome with a covering umbrella. Located on the banks of Gomati River, the foundation of this remarkable tourist place in Lucknow was laid by Nawab Ghazi-ud-din Haider. However, the construction of Chhatar Mazil got complete in the reign of his son - Nasir-ud-din Haider. The architecture of this historical building boasts a beautiful fusion of both Indian and European architectural style. The Lucknow Satkhanda is a tall and old tower in Lucknow, India. It has seven floors and looks a bit like a watchtower. It's like a time machine that takes us back to the past and shows how things were in old times. People think it's special because it's a part of the city's history and reminds us of the past.

Satkhanda is a Watchtower situated just adjacent to Hussainabad Clock Tower in Lucknow. As the name suggests Satkhanda means 7 floors but only 4 floors constructed of it. Incomplete but nevertheless splendour of heritage architecture, Satkhnada, a red-brick watch-tower, constructed by King Mohammed Ali Shah.Satkhanda, a four-storey tower, has got it’s architectural design influenced from ‘The Leaning Tower of Pisa’, one of the seven wonders of world. The tower is constructed in a blend of Greek and Islamic architecture. The height of the octagonal ground floor of this structure is almost 10 feet, making it the highest storey of this tower. One of the distinctive feature of this structure is that each of it’s successive storey has been constructed in the decreasing order of height and breadth of it’s base storey. The total height of Satkhanda is 35 feet approximately.When you are planning to explore the Lucknow city you can add this beautiful octagonal tower to your list.Visited on
Weekend

The old city area of Lucknow is replete with historical monuments so much so that it seems to be taken straight out of a history book. Most of the monuments built by the Nawabs of Awadh portray a rich blend of Mughal, British, and Persian architecture at its best. One such magnificent structure, which unfortunately could not reach completion, is the #Satkhanda, situated in the Hussainabad area of the city.The tower was built by Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah in 1842. Originally, the plan was to build 30 meters high, seven-storey tower but the construction work was abandoned after the untimely death of Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah. By that time, only four storeys could be completed. The tower is approximately 21 meters high and was built to view the moon by the Ulema as Muslims celebrate Eid, Bakreed  festivals according to the sighting of the moon. Moreover, Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah wanted to have an extensive bird’s eye view of the wonderful city of Lucknow along with the majestic monuments and buildings from Satkhanda.According to some local historians, the Nawab used to love his daughter immensely and wanted to build the monument for her. Unfortunately, the Nawab’s daughter is said to have died at a tender age. Soon after the untimely death of his daughter, Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah also died as he was unable to bear the loss of his daughter. The construction of the Satkhanda tower was abruptly stopped after the death of Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah and the descendants of the Nawab did not undertake the completion of the construction because they thought it would be a bad omen. Some locals believe that Nawab Mohammad Ali Shah hurt his ankle badly while climbing the stairs of the tower and died soon after this incident. Perhaps, this was the reason behind the reluctance of the Nawab’s descendants to avoid resuming the construction of Satkhanda, considering it a bad omen.#Lucknow #HometownThe old city area of Lucknow is replete with historical monuments so much so that it seems to be taken straight out of a history book. Most of the monuments built by the Nawabs of Awadh portray a rich blend of Mughal, British, and Persian

इंदौर शहर और आसपास के अन्य शहरों के नागरिकों को खजराना मंदिर में बहुत विश्वास है। यह मंदिर बहादुर मराठा रानी अहिल्याबाई होल्कर द्वारा बनाया गया था। यह हिंदुओं का एक महत्वपूर्ण स्थान है।खजराना गणेश मंदिर का निर्माण रानी अहिल्याबाई होल्कर ने करवाया था। यह मंदिर भारत के प्रसिद्ध हिंदू मंदिरों में से एक है। ज्यादातर बुधवार एवं रविवार को विशाल संख्या मे लोग दर्शन करने के लिए इस मंदिर में आते हैं। एक स्थानीय मान्यता के अनुसार, इस मंदिर में पूजा करने पर भक्तों की सभी मनोकामनाएं पूरी होती हैं। इस मंदिर का मुख्य त्योहार विनायक चतुर्थी है और इसे अगस्त और सितंबर के महीने में भव्य तरीके से आयोजित किया जाता हैमंदिर को सरकार ने अपने कब्जे में ले लिया है। मंदिर का प्रबंधन भट्ट परिवार द्वारा किया जाता है। ऐसा माना जाता है कि औरंगजेब से मूर्ति की रक्षा करने के लिए, मूर्ति को एक कुएं में छिपा दिया गया था और 1735 में, इसे कुएं से निकाल लिया गया था और 1735 में एक मंदिर की स्थापना अहिल्याबाई होल्कर द्वारा की गई थी, जो मराठा के होली वंश से संबंधित थी। साम्राज्य।पिछले कुछ वर्षों में मंदिर का काफी विकास हुआ है। यह एक छोटी झोपड़ी से एक विशाल मंदिर और शहर में सबसे प्रतिष्ठित मंदिर के रूप में विकसित हुआ है। मंदिर में सोने, हीरे और अन्य बहुमूल्य रत्नों का नियमित दान किया जाता है। गर्भगृह की बाहरी दीवार और दीवार चांदी से बनी है और इस पर विभिन्न मनोदशाओं और उत्सवों का चित्रण किया गया है। देवता की आंखें हीरे से बनी होती हैं जो इंदौर के एक व्यवसायी ने दान में दी थीं। गर्भगृह की ऊपरी दीवार चांदी से बनी है।इंदौर शहर और आसपास के अन्य शहरों के नागरिकों को खजराना मंदिर में बहुत विश्वास है। यह मंदिर बहादुर मराठा रानी अहिल्याबाई होल्कर द्वारा बनाया गया था। यह हिंदुओं का एक महत्वपूर्ण स्थान है।

The citizens of Indore city and other nearby cities have great faith in Khajrana Temple. This temple was built by the brave Maratha queen Ahilyabai Holkar. This is an important place for Hindus.Khajrana Ganesh Temple was built by Queen Ahilyabai Holkar. This temple is one of the famous Hindu temples of India. Mostly on Wednesdays and Sundays, a large number of people come to this temple for darshan. According to a local belief, all the wishes of the devotees are fulfilled when they worship in this temple. The main festival of this temple is Vinayaka Chaturthi and it is organized in a grand manner in the month of August and SeptemberThe government has taken possession of the temple. The temple is managed by the Bhatt family. It is believed that to protect the idol from Aurangzeb, the idol was hidden in a well and in 1735, it was taken out of the well and in 1735 a temple was established by Ahilyabai Holkar, who was a Maratha. Belonged to the Holi dynasty. Empire.The temple has developed significantly over the years. It has grown from a small hut to a huge temple and the most revered temple in the city. Gold, diamonds and other precious gems are regularly donated to the temple. The outer walls and walls of the sanctum sanctorum are made of silver and various moods and festivals are depicted on it. The eyes of the deity are made of diamonds which were donated by an Indore businessman. The upper wall of the sanctum sanctorum is made of silver.The citizens of Indore city and other nearby cities have great faith in Khajrana Temple. This temple was built by the brave Maratha queen Ahilyabai Holkar. This is an important place for Hindus.

It's a great palace with very unique European Style architecture not commonly seen in Indian monuments. Entry fee is Rs 20. Renovation work of the royal palace is underway.Spread over 76 acres of property, the construction of the 45-room palace happened in three phases. Starting with Tukojirao Holkar II in 1886, who acquired this property and was completed under his grandson, Tukojirao Holkar III in 1926. It is built in the Italian Renaissance Revival architecture style[1] and once had a 20-acre rose garden, while its main gates are modelled after those at the Buckingham Palace, by Triggs of Calcutta.After the death of Tukojirao Holkar III in 1978, his third wife, an American, Sharmishtha Devi (formerly Nancy Anne Miller) moved out and subsequently, the palace was converted into a museum. Much of the first floor was destroyed in a fire. In the 1980s, the palace fell into disrepair and was prone to theft of its antiques before the state government acquired the property in 1987.Visited on

I recently visited Patalpani Waterfall in Indore. The waterfall is located amidst lush greenery and the surrounding natural beauty is truly mesmerizing.The waterfall itself is quite impressive, with water cascading down from a height and creating a soothing sound. The sight of the water falling and the mist it creates is absolutely stunning. It's a perfect spot for nature lovers and photographers.The area around the waterfall is well-maintained and clean. There are seating areas where visitors can relax and enjoy the view. There are also small food stalls selling snacks and refreshments, which is convenient for those who want to spend more time there.Overall, my experience at Patalpani Waterfall was fantastic. The natural beauty, peaceful atmosphere, and the refreshing waterfall made it a perfect getaway from the city. I highly recommend visiting this place if you're in Indore.Visited on

Nahar Singh Mahal is a historical palace located in Ballabhgarh city of Haryana. The palace was built in the late 18th century by the Jat ruler, Raja Nahar Singh, and served as his residence. Today, the palace is a popular tourist attraction and a popular location for film shoots.The palace has an impressive architecture, showcasing the blend of Mughal and Rajput styles. It has beautifully decorated halls, courtyards, and balconies, reflecting the grandeur and opulence of the bygone era. The palace is well-maintained and has undergone restoration work, which has helped to preserve its beauty and historical significance.Apart from the palace, there is a beautiful garden surrounding it, which is perfect for a leisurely stroll. The palace also has a museum, which showcases the history and heritage of the palace and the Jat rulers.Overall, Nahar Singh Mahal is a must-visit tourist attraction in Ballabhgarh, offering a glimpse of the rich cultural and historical heritage of the region.Nahar Singh Mahal is a historical palace located in Ballabhgarh city of Haryana. There is ample space for parking and one does have to descend around 100 metres on a step way and then one reaches the main temple with Shri Krishna and Srimati Radharani present on the altar their. There is a kitchen there and Pandit ji served us Prasad at aroun 1:30 PM and tea at around 4 PM! Soo welcoming!! Didn't know right in Faridabad we have this lovely place! The Surajkund Craft Mela in Delhi is a vibrant celebration of traditional arts, crafts, and culture that mesmerizes visitors from near and far. Stepping into this enchanting fair feels like entering a world steeped in artistic splendor and rich heritage. The Mela, held annually in Surajkund, showcases the diverse craftsmanship of India's talented artisans, with over 400 stalls offering an incredible array of handmade treasures.One cannot help but be captivated by the sheer creativity and skill on display. From intricate handwoven textiles to intricately carved wooden sculptures, each item tells a story of generations of craftsmanship and dedication to preserving traditional techniques. The Mela is a treasure trove for those seeking unique souvenirs or one-of-a-kind pieces to adorn their homes.What truly sets the Surajkund Craft Mela apart is its lively atmosphere. Traditional folk music and dance performances fill the air, immersing visitors in the rich cultural tapestry of India. The vibrant colors of traditional costumes, the rhythmic beats of drums, and the twirling movements of dancers create an electric ambiance that resonates with the soul.The Mela also tantalizes the taste buds with a wide array of regional delicacies. From piping hot street food to traditional sweets, every culinary delight reflects the diverse flavors of India. Indulging in these delectable treats while exploring the Mela adds an extra layer of delight to the experience.Moreover, the Mela offers a platform for artisans to showcase their talents and sustain their livelihoods. By supporting the craftsmen and women, visitors contribute to the preservation of India's cultural heritage and the continuation of age-old techniques.However, the popularity of the Surajkund Craft Mela does mean that it can get crowded, especially on weekends. Navigating through the bustling stalls can be a challenge, and it's advisable to arrive early to beat the crowds.In summary, the Surajkund Craft Mela in Delhi is a captivating celebration of Indian art, craft, and culture. It offers a kaleidoscope of sights, sounds, and flavors that immerse visitors in the beauty and diversity of India's traditional craftsmanship. With its vibrant ambiance, rich heritage, and a treasure trove of handcrafted wonders, the Mela is an experience that should not be missed by anyone seeking to explore the essence of Indian culture.Wait time

Used as a water resource untill the British came, this kund/ pool is the name behind the Surajkund. It once was the reservoir to meet the water need of the surrounding area.Curved to the East to pay respect to the rising sun it's named Surajkund- The Pool of Sun as the Tomars, who built it around 10th CE  were sun worshippers.The lake has dried up and we were 15 minutes late; the closing time is 6pm, so we couldn't visit it. However the vastness of the site was visible from the road and I was impressed my the 6 acres of it,  with stone steps built of HUGE stones surrounding the lake like some amphitheatre of Romans, complete with a ramp and a sort of seat perhaps for the king?The entire structure gave an ancient vibe of being at some historical archeological site.I wish, I was 15 minutes early.But then, it gave me a reason to visit it again for sure.Used as a water resource untill the British came, this kund/ pool is the name behind the Surajkund. It once was the reservoir to meet the water need of the surrounding area.
